As you may well know, for the last two years, I’ve been working with John and Mary Jo at a school in Cambodia where I’ve met some phenomenal kids. They are poor, some of them even in extreme poverty, and they are learning everything they know not only through the schools they attend, but through the parents who help them. My first post about this issue can be read here.

At present, all the kids are too young to know exactly what a computer is, but over time, John and I are introducing them to an important issue known as e-government and this is how. John and I were discussing our work today and I told him that I can’t stop thinking about how we can keep the kids engaged, so we decided to find an online tool that will enable them to create an e-portfolio of digital stories. We want them to be the teachers of our time and this allows them to keep learning and growing beyond what many of their teachers do. John, Mary Jo and I all think it’s worth including the digital stories into the e-learning portfolio so it could mean quite a lot for the kids and their future success as they try to overcome a lifetime of deprivation to pursue a college education. In my spare time at home, and I do have quite a bit, I’m looking at creating an e-learning platform. It’s been about two years since we last had a serious talk about our digital future, as I was in Cambodia and it was tough to get online. We do want to go through a few things and as John has a day job, we were looking at something that would enable him to work part-time as a fulltime digital missionary. This gave the idea of creating an e-learning platform that you have to pay to use, but it’s only a drop in the ocean compared to the education they will eventually access. The platform would have to be developed locally but the idea is that you could develop your own e-portfolio as a team and share them with others. It will be based on Drupal and the idea with the kids is to allow them to take ownership. I do a lot with my Drupal skills but I’m not going to build everything from nothing. It will have a bit of everything and not a lot of anything. I want it to have a lot of “everything”! My plan is to use Open Courseware, Moodle and YouTube to help with

In this blog I’ll be sharing tips and tricks that I’ve learned when I’ve been able to get the attention (and support) of my players as a Dungeon Master. Of course, this will involve tips for running in the D&D 5e ruleset, but a lot of these tips will probably be relevant to Dungeon Masters of other games as well.

When my players find things I didn’t anticipate, when they’d like a certain kind of monster to feature more prominently, when they’re unhappy with something I did, etc., here’s how I handle it. Here are a few things I’ve found to be very helpful tools:

Don’t sweat it when you make “mistakes.” Instead, recognize that it’s probably human to make mistakes from time to time. The mistake is not in the mistake you make, but in the fact that they exist at all. What’s not human is making mistakes over and over again. (In D&D, this is a fairly reliable sign of a player playing an intentionally artificial character. Players shouldn’t tend to make bad rolls this often or be so stubborn in their mistakes for a DM who has clearly made an effort to anticipate most of these kinds of things.)

Don’t bother with “fixing the mistake.” The first step in this kind of problem is realizing that mistakes are inevitable; the next step is trying to eliminate all the mistakes. If they insist on a particularly poor idea or if they’re unhappy with the result, that’s fine, but don’t waste effort fixing what’s already been fixed.

Don’t be afraid of players who say, “But I thought he would have x!” The phrase is “But I thought He” which implies that it’s a mistake I made, which means it’s likely not mine and not something that I did intentionally. I don’t take it personally if I didn’t expect that particular event. I try to assume that every player assumes every scenario will go the way they want it to — otherwise no one would bother playing the game.

Don’t feel bad when they get angry. Every DM goes through times when they make a mistake, don’t anticipate the players well, or simply screw something up. When the

Hepatitis B and human immunodeficiency virus among hemodialysis patients.
To determine the incidence of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, the prevalence of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and the incidence of hepatitis B-related illness (HBRI) among hemodialysis patients, we performed a retrospective study over a period of 36 months. In addition, the response to hepatitis B vaccination was tested over a follow-up period of 12 months. The prevalence of HBsAg at entry to hemodialysis treatment was 8.9 +/- 0.2% (mean +/- SE). There was no significant correlation between patients younger than 30 years of age and the prevalence of HBsAg. In contrast, age was significantly correlated with the prevalence of HIV antibodies. In general, older patients had a lower prevalence of HBsAg and HIV antibodies than did younger patients. During the follow-up period, the incidence of HBsAg seroclearance and seroconversion was 0.27 and 0.22%, respectively. No significant correlation was found between the presence of HBsAg and the development of HBRI. HBV vaccination was administered to 628 patients in a single dose at initiation of treatment. After 10 and 12 months a follow-up questionnaire was administered to evaluate the immunogenicity of the vaccines. The immune response was seroprotective in 907 of 918 (98.9%) patients. We conclude that the prevalence of serologic markers of HBV infection in our cohort is less than that reported for patients during dialysis therapy before the introduction of nucleoside analogs to treat hepatitis B. No evidence of hepatitis B replication was found. HBV vaccination in hemodialysis patients was well accepted, and protection against HBV infection was elicited in the majority of patients.

Efficacy of amifostine combination with chemotherapy after high-dose chemotherapy for myeloma.
The present study evaluated the efficacy of a combination of amifostine and fludarabine/cyclophosphamide in patients with previously untreated multiple myeloma undergoing intensified regimens. This phase II study evaluated 41 patients who were treated with the four-drug regimen of cyclophosphamide (600 mg/m2), BCNU (50 mg/m2), melphalan (30 mg/m2), and vincristine (1.4 mg/m2) followed by fludarabine (30 mg/m2) and amifostine (3000 mg/m2). Hematologic toxicity was well tolerated and included myelosuppression in 32 patients (78%), diarrhea in 18 (44%). Thrombocytopenia was > or = grade 6 in only two patients. No thrombohemorrhagic complications were reported. Twenty-three patients responded (79%) for a complete response and 11 (41%) for a very good partial response (VGPR). The survival rate was 45% (three-year survival rate) and 36% (median survival time). A Cox regression analysis identified three pretreatment characteristics as significant prognostic factors: serum creatinine level, performance status, and time from initial diagnosis to therapy. These three covariates were included in the multivariate analysis for the prediction of survival. Overall survival was best in patients pretreated with vincristine-containing regimens. The survival rate was 44% in those pretreated with both vincristine and cyclophosphamide, compared with 16% in the other patients; the corresponding time intervals for survival were 13.2 versus 22.9 months (P =.018). Overall survival was also favorable in patients with a renal clearance of > or = 30 mL/min compared with < 30 mL/min (P =.044). Patients pretreated with the four-drug regimen showed a superior response rate, a significantly longer time to progression (median time: 11.5 months), and a significantly longer survival (median: 25.6 months) than did the patients who were not pretreated with this intensified regimen. The addition of amifostine seems to further improve the antitumor activity of this intensified cyclophosphamide containing regimen. Can't connect to a SQL Server using Visual Studio 2013.NET Framework 4.5

I've created a database in SSMS 2012 Express and I'm trying to connect it in VS 2013 with my VS project. My project works very well with the SSMS 2008 Express. It is because of the SQL Server 2012.
I've installed SSMS 2012 Express and checked the TCP/IP protocol.
(SSMS 2012 Express - Configuration -> Networking)

I've also installed Microsoft SQL Server Integration Services, because in SSMS 2012 Express the package can't work with SQL Server 2012 (SQL Server Express)
(SSMS 2012 Express -> Configuration -> Management Tools -> SQL Server Integration Services -> Tasks -> Install and Setup SQL Server 2012 Integration Services)

I've installed SQL Server LocalDB also because with SSMS 2012 Express it doesn't allow to connect with SQL Server 2012 Express.
(SQL Server 2012 Express -> Configuration -> Tools -> LocalDB)

And I've tested many times the database in my VS project.
I've tried also connect the database by using ODBC and without ODBC but nothing.
I need help to solve the above errors.

A:

You have SQL Express 2012 installed then right? So on your VS IDE you should go to menu Tools->options->SQL Server Data Tools->SQL Server(on the left menu) and check Enable Connections to Installed SQL Server from the menu, if this is not selected and not checked you wont be able to connect to your database on Visual Studio (and it won't have the same version you installed on SSMS).

There are trade-offs of language choices like dynamic type systems versus static type systems, and there’s no perfect solution. We all try to do the best we can, and we can’t please everyone.

To be fair, the post is not completely about Martin. More on the specific issues are covered by the three sections mentioned.

To quote some things I found relevant:

How do you decide what to work on next using Haskell, Scala or Clojure as a language?

I think I work on my next big project as I have the chance. But I don’t work on big projects every month, I have no big plans so I’d have enough time to be working on nothing. In my current project, I want to focus on one task at a time.

How do you balance projects that have more documentation and library support than some people prefer?

I always spend some time deciding if it’s a library I want to use for a bigger project or if it’s the small thing I want to try. I don’t want to get in the habit of picking a project with just one type of library. And I don’t want to put off any project because I know it won’t have the library I want on first look.

I’m not sure what my ideal balance is. I try to be as productive as possible, without having too much or even too many libraries. You’re right to mention that there are problems of too many libraries but, then again, you only need a handful of library for most projects.

Evaluation of human lung injury in mechanically ventilated septic patients.
Multiple organs are affected by sepsis, pulmonary dysfunction is the most common organ failure, and mechanical ventilation (MV) with high oxygen concentrations contributes to the lung injury. There is an urgent need to develop valid diagnostic tools for the identification of patients at risk of organ failure. The aim of this study was to test whether early alterations in the microvascular blood flow may provide information on lung injury during high-dose inhalational anesthesia. Prospective observational study. Medical teaching hospital. Fourteen septic patients with acute lung injury/acute lung injury syndrome (ARDS) were mechanically ventilated, and a continuous infusion of remifentanil was used to maintain anesthesia. Microvascular blood flow was measured noninvasively, and arterial and lung capillary pressure were measured invasively. Lung injury was assessed at 2.5-7.25 hrs of MV by bronchoalveolar lavage and measurements of lung mechanics, diffusing capacity, and microvascular blood flow. Lung injury was present in 5 of 6 patients who received high oxygen concentrations and in 7 of 8 patients who received lower oxygen concentrations (p = 0.04). Increased capillary pressure was present in the patients who received high PEEP levels (p = 0.01). The highest lung injury scores were associated with the presence of arterial oxygen saturation, PaO2/FIO2 ratio, lung compliance, PEEP, lung volume recruitment, and ventilation with low inspiratory pressure (p < 0.05). Microvascular blood flow decreased in patients who tolerated MV at high oxygen concentrations, and a lung injury score > or = 5 was associated with higher capillary pressures (p = 0.004). However, microvascular blood flow significantly increased in patients who had increased lung injury scores at ventilation with low inspiratory pressure (p = 0.002). Lung injury can be identified during MV, and patients at risk of lung injury should be identified. Microvascular blood flow measured noninvasively is a sensitive and specific marker for ventilatory-induced lung injury.

[Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and interstitial fibrosis].
We experienced a case of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) who had pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) concomitantly. He was a 63 year old male, complaining of a dry cough and dyspnea. He had been diagnosed as IPF in a local hospital and had received prednisolone since April 1998. Because the serum level of surfactant was increased, the treatment with prednisolone was replaced with cyclosporine A (CSA). After this treatment the serum level of surfactant was dramatically elevated. At that time he was admitted to our hospital. On admission, chest CT demonstrated diffuse reticular abnormality. Open lung biopsy was performed and pathological findings revealed PAP concomitantly with IPF. Since corticosteroid was discontinued, symptoms did not improve. Cyclosporine A was also discontinued. However he died of respiratory failure and multiple organ failure several years later.

More particularly, it relates to a hand-operated device for measuring the amount of salt, sand and other impurities in the water of a vehicle's cooling system, as well as the amount of deposit materials which collect in water-carrier conduits and components to which water is exposed.
In a vehicle the cooling system of its engine is dependent upon a source of heat-dissipating water such as an engine's radiator which requires considerable water to operate properly.
The amount of water required for the vehicle's cooling system depends greatly upon the amount and characteristics of the water in its "coolant" supplied to the automobile engine. If the coolant water is impure, either in chemical or mineral composition, the engine will not operate efficiently either cold-starting or in warm weather.
Conventional cooling systems circulate either fresh or antifreeze coolant continuously through passages in which the engine's cylinder heads and other engine components are mounted on a base to take on, and dissipate, heat from the engine's cylinder heads, and to remove the heat generated during engine operation. The water in the cooling system flows through hoses or lines which carry the heated coolant to the radiator for heat-exchange and to the engine "water jackets" for dissipation of the heat of conduction through the engine block, head, and pistons carried by the engine's crank-pin to the coolant water in the cylinders.
Since engines have been built to operate for years, and have accumulated a great deal of corrosion and deposit material from engine use, the normal coolant water becomes mired with impurity, especially when operated in the hot summers or heated engine rooms of vehicles.
The amount of deposit material in the coolant can vary greatly. For instance, as stated earlier, water becomes clogged with deposit material either when the engine is either cold-started or warm weather vehicles. As the deposits build up in the engine's water jackets and other internal-components containing coolant water conduits, the engine becomes less efficient. Depending on the type of vehicle in which this occurs, the engine either will not start, or will not power on, or will operate very erratically under a given set of operating conditions.

This is a blog entry I wrote for the book ‘Mapping a New Reality: The Emergence of the Modern’ by Peter Toren. This is the description. Here is a link to read the book online. This is an excerpt and I will link the full post at the bottom of this entry. Read the post here. From: David Gidley

In the year 2200, the world you know today will be utterly unrecognisable. The air will be clean and free of pollution. The seas will support a full ecosystem of ocean life. There will be a complete interdependence of people and planet, of all living things, to ensure mankind’s survival. This is the world we are now embarking upon as technological, medical and human development unfolds, providing us with ever brighter futures for ourselves and our children. At the same time, a darker world of dangers and dangers awaits those who allow their planet and their fellow people to be stripped away by those who would lead the way to a world of their making. We have long been aware of this danger.

Our history tells us that this is a perilous path to walk, and yet we persevere. In the last century much has been learned in our efforts across the planet to achieve a clean and stable planet, and to provide for all its inhabitants. Through our collective action and hard-working dedication, we have built a world in which not only can we live, but should we choose to, we too can thrive as a society.

To those who believe that we have not achieved all we need to build a world of our dreams and ambitions, to those who believe that this world we have built can and should be changed, you are wrong. If we were to walk away from our hard-won achievements there would be no other safe alternative beyond a world of darkness. While there has been much conflict, and much fear about who are the ‘other’ and the threat they are to our world, now our most important enemy, that which has shaped the history of our world and will shape your world as well, is not the outsider, the stranger, or any of our neighbours. It is within. In the year 2200 it will no longer matter if the threat that we face to protect our world will come from the north, or the south, or the east; the threat is still the same. It is within that we will face that danger, not because of others, but because of ourselves.

Cordova, Georgia

Cordova is a city in Jackson and Upson counties in the state of Georgia. The population was 2,984 at the 2010 census. It is known for being the birthplace of blues musician Robert Johnson and it has been featured on Ghost Adventures.

History
Cordova was originally called "Ridgeville," but was renamed Cordova in about 1879 when the Georgia legislature passed a law re-establishing the original county boundaries.

In the early 1900s, Robert Johnson and his band visited Cordova. The young Robert Johnson stayed with the local musicians until he gained enough experience to join the Atlanta Blues Hall of Fame in the 1970s. Robert Johnson was buried in Cordova Cemetery, located in the southwestern part of the city of Cordova. Cordova received city status in 1968.

The city was featured on episode 11 of season seven of the A&E television series Ghost Hunters.

Geography

Cordova is located at  (33.291638, -81.481608). At an elevation of, Cordova is the highest point in Jackson County, but is slightly lower at  than its neighboring city in Upson County, Watertown (the difference in elevation between Cordova and Watertown is the result of two major engineering mistakes made by the city of Watertown when it founded itself. This, in itself, is quite ironic as Watertown is a relatively small community of around 1,000. It has been said that this mistake, and the subsequent growth of the city, was the "Watertown Hurricane.")

According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of.   of which is land and  (1.13%) is water.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 3,000 people, 1,214 households, and 854 families residing in the city.  The population density is 683.9 people per square mile (263.6/km²).  There were 1,329 housing units at an average density of 290.2 per square mile (112.6/km²).  The racial makeup of the city was 81.75% White, 15.40% African American, 0.20% Native American, 0.20% Asian, 0.40% from other races, and 1.40% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.00% of the population.

The present invention, in some embodiments thereof, relates to video encoding and, more particularly, but not exclusively, to video encoding using hierarchical prediction.
Hierarchial Prediction is a technique of spatially distributing prediction, which allows an image with more coding efficiency than traditional motion estimation. According to another technique, a block with high importance to the reference frame is selected prior to prediction and all pixels in the block are predicted, even though motion compensation may be required only in a portion of the pixels. This is generally referred to as block based prediction. Generally, the pixel-to-pixel prediction (PTP) mode utilizes less bits than motion compensated prediction and is more efficient, but only possible if both color and texture of the block to be encoded are equal to those previously available. That is, the reference frame must have color and texture identical to the one used to predict.
Hierarchial prediction encodes a motion vector in order to select a best match block from a current frame (or from previously encoded frames) that is most similar to the current frame (or frames). The best match block is assumed to be a prediction for pixels in the current frame that are not predicted by any reference block. The spatial reference frame is composed of multiple blocks which can be the same size (i.e., intra prediction) or multiple same sized reference blocks (i.e., inter prediction).
Hierarchial prediction can be implemented in a variety of forms using motion vectors, with a simple motion vector indicating best match location of a block in a previous or future frame, or with a complex motion vector indicating both best match location and the prediction error for the selected reference block.

The invention relates generally to methods and apparatus of generating, controlling and directing a laser beam and a pulsed or continuously burning plasma for space propulsion and specifically to the implementation and control of the ignition, acceleration and guiding of such a propulsion beam that can result in the generation of a rocket's thrust with laser beam intensity controlled in order to be able to avoid excessive heating of nearby critical parts in the vicinity of the plasma.
To date, plasma sources have not been able to produce high temperature plasmas in the range of 10,000.degree.K for sustained periods of time long enough to produce usable kinetic energies for space propulsion purposes. Such high temperatures are required in order to accelerate the plasma to a useful velocity.
A number of investigators, including J. S. Burch and M. Stahle (Plasma Sources Sci., 3, 65 (1994)) have demonstrated the feasibility of using a high power, highly directed laser beam, having a central axis to direct the high power beam to impinge on an explosive charge. Such beams have included a highly focused beam having a central axis to impinge upon an explosive charge. J. S. Burch and M. Stahle used a laser-based ignition system to initiate the detonation of an aluminum powder mixture in a closed chamber holding the mixture, which produced an ablation plasma having a temperature of 10,000.degree.K. A subsequent test demonstrated that a continuous ignition of a methane/nitrogen/oxygen mixture could produce 10,000 K plasma for 7 ms.
Unfortunately, for most purposes, such sources must produce a high velocity thrust to operate, while maintaining very low heat deposition. This requires a plasma having a significantly higher temperature.
To do this, one approach would be to provide a focused laser beam of sufficient optical power to provide both optical excitation of the target gas and a source of optical fluence to cause the optical breakdown of the target gas into its constituent atomic or sub-atomic species. Such a laser excitation would provide the necessary optical energy to both excite the atoms and provide the required optical fluence. Once that is done, the remaining problems would be the confinement of the plasma itself.
This approach requires a well-directed, preferably collimated and possibly shaped, high power radiation beam that would be focussed onto the surface of the target fuel.

The effect of dietary sucrose on the plasma and urinary free amino acid composition in rats.
Sucrose is a non-digestible but potentially toxic carbohydrate present in the intestinal lumen that escapes digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract. Dietary sucrose has been shown to produce hyperammonaemia and impaired growth in rats. Studies have suggested that the effects observed might be related to the presence of the disaccharide in the diet. This study examined the effects of dietary sucrose on the plasma and urinary free amino acid (FAA) composition in the rat. Sprague-Dawley rats were divided into four dietary groups: standard rat chow (control diet), standard rat chow supplemented with sucrose (sucrose diet), sucrose-free rat chow (placebo diet) and standard rat chow containing sucrose and the disaccharide 2, 3, 5-tri-O-acetyl-D-ribitol (2:3-O-TRIAC:TRIAC diet). After 14 days of dietary treatment, the rats were killed and their plasma and urine collected, the latter of which was deproteinated. The FAA were quantified by high-performance liquid chromatography or amino acid analysis. Rats on the sucrose-containing diets had significantly higher plasma and urinary ammonia (as a measure of increased nitrogen excretion) compared with the corresponding controls fed standard rat chow (P<0.05), while on the 2:3-O-TRIAC:TRIAC diet, they also had significantly higher plasma urea compared with all other groups (P<0.05). Rats on standard rat chow supplemented with sucrose had significantly lower plasma levels of all the aromatic AA but significantly higher levels of some essential AA compared with the controls, whereas on the 2:3-O-TRIAC:TRIAC diet, the opposite was found. The study indicated that the diets can modify the levels of amino acids in plasma and urine, with significant alterations in the distribution of the aromatic AA only. On a sucrose-containing diet, there is no evidence of accumulation of ammonia or any other FAA beyond the physiological levels, although the aromatic AA in plasma and certain essential AA in plasma can be significantly reduced. On the 2:3-O-TRIAC:TRIAC diet, a slight reduction in the levels of some aromatic and essential AA in plasma, and a significantly raised level of ammonia, were observed. In The Name of Humanity: The Human Experience in an Era of Global Uncertainty and Instability

The concept of globalization has existed for several centuries and is now a reality that we all live as the world becomes one integrated global community, with everyone connected to everyone else and all economic and social activities occurring around the world being affected by the ever-changing global environment and processes. All aspects of life are affected by global change – from economic markets to weather to politics to health care. Globalization also affects how we think, plan, imagine and experience the world around us.

The concept of globalization has existed for several centuries and is now a reality that we all live as the world becomes one integrated global community, with everyone connected to everyone else and all economic and social activities occurring around the world being affected by the ever-changing global environment and processes. All aspects of life are affected by global change – from economic markets to weather to politics to health care. Globalization also affects how we think, plan, imagine and experience the world around us.

Globalization is now widely understood and accepted by most to be beneficial to the international community. There are, however, some who still question the effects of globalization on nations and people, especially in light of some recent economic events. Are they correct to do so? Can it be that those who are opposed to globalization are actually the ones being harmed by it, and not those who support it?

Dr. Henry J. Schwartz is a Harvard University professor and author of the critically acclaimed bestselling book The Real World of Money. In this book, Dr. Schwartz provides an excellent analysis of what globalization has contributed to global change since it first appeared in the 19th century. He presents a clear and detailed analysis of globalization, its historical roots and the social and psychological aspects of its implementation.

“In The Name of Humanity” provides a deeper look at the benefits and challenges of globalization. In the modern era, the effects of globalization have been widely experienced; the book provides an authoritative, thorough survey of their impact. According to the author, globalization is the creation of a global economic order and a comprehensive web of global interdependencies resulting in the elimination of national boundaries between market participants. Thus, a significant and far-reaching impact has been made on the human experience as a result of globalization.

The primary objective of this work is to explore in detail, the nature of globalization and to explore the role of globalization as it affects the human experience on a global level

Nasal NK and T cells differ in immunoregulatory potency.
During early life, the respiratory tract is a major site of initiation of immunity to antigenic challenge. Although, in adults, the respiratory mucosa is generally thought to be sterile when immunologically naive, several studies demonstrate the presence of lymphoid cells throughout the respiratory mucosa (nasal-associated lymphoid tissue). The present study examined whether the immune cells found in the epithelial layer and in nasal-associated lymphoid tissue had equivalent functional responses when stimulated in vitro and challenged in vitro. To induce immune responses, lymph node cells were incubated during 2 days with cytokines (IL-2, IL-4, IL-10) and with or without nasal antigen. The immune cells were then challenged by in vitro culture and exposure to rhubarb. The nasal NK cells and a subpopulation of NK cells, but not the majority of T cells, responded to rhubarb by increasing degranulation, killing and secreting cytokines. The nasal T cells were more responsive to IFN-γ. The NK cells were able to kill Rh mucosal vaccine-bearing bacteria even though this was not enhanced in the presence of IL-4. Since NK cells may be capable of producing IFN-γ when exposed to the nasal vaccine, they may be used effectively to enhance mucosal vaccine-induced immunity and in the eradication of the rhinovirus.

Is there a way to display the file that is opened with Windows Explorer in Visual Studio?

I am using Visual Studio 2015, and I would like to access the file that is opened in Windows Explorer. Is there a way to see the path of the file that is being opened with windows explorer?
I've seen that with some other tools there is an option that specifies a location where all opened files are logged but such option does not exist for Windows Explorer.

A:

When you open an existing file with Windows Explorer, the file path is opened.
Ctrl+Shift+P --> Type r: (for open dialog)
Go to the location tab, and click on browse, and select the file.

You can go a step further, and set Visual Studio to open files that match a pattern when you start debugging.

Q:

How do I run a SQL query using the Django ORM?

I'm using a Django site and I want to add a "Run Query" button in admin panel to run a specific query. I'm using the Django ORM to make an API, not sure if that has anything to do with it.

A:

It depends. Assuming that you are using the admin panel with the database (e.g. Postgres) as backend (you can use django orm, django-mysql or something else):
If you're in the python shell:
from django.db.models.sql import QuerySet
qs = QuerySet()
qs.from_queryset("MyModel")
for obj in qs:
    # do stuff

If you're not in the python shell you can run raw query
from django.db import connection
cursor = connection.cursor()
cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM MyModel")
results = cursor.fetchall() # or some other methods
for obj in results:
    # do stuff

You should note that to generate a view with list(YourApp.YourModel.objects.all()) you can use get_queryset:
from django.views import list

def listView(request):
    # your queryset, e.g.
    #
    # from django.db.models import Q
    #
    # queryset = Q(status=1) | Q()
    # qs = queryset.all()    # you can put here anything except queryset.all()
    # 
    # return HttpResponse(serialize(qs), mimetype="application/json")
    # you can return whatever format you want and then in the view you serialize your raw values...

And if you are writing your own python application then you can use python sqlite3 module

Mortality in patients with multiple myeloma with different types of treatment strategies.
A retrospective study of the effect of various treatment strategies on survival in 441 patients newly diagnosed with multiple myeloma in Norway and Denmark (1972-79) was conducted. The median follow-up time was 3.6 years. The overall survival time from diagnosis for the whole group has improved significantly from 3.9 years in 1972-74 to 7.3 years in 1971-75. The proportion of patients receiving alkylating agent-containing initial therapy (44%, P not significant), the introduction of high-dose melphalan (16%, P less than 0.05), and increased numbers of patients starting maintenance therapy with 6-mercaptopurine and/or methotrexate (41%, P less than 0.05) significantly increased the 5-year survival time from 18% in 1972-74 to 37% in 1979. However, no significant impact could be seen from the implementation of autologous transplantation (6%, P = not significant) or the increasing use of immunomodulatory drugs (0%, P = not significant). These four treatment strategies may have resulted in increased survival, but it is difficult to attribute this to any single factor. Increased survival is also seen in the subset of patients with serum creatinine levels exceeding 3.0 mg/L or who are older than 65 years. In general, the number of patients who receive any initial treatment regimen was low. The present results seem to indicate that the introduction of initial treatment has resulted in improved survival of a larger proportion of patients than is seen in the current studies.

Q:

In Python, what is the difference between calling an instance method on any object and calling it directly?

In Python, what is the difference between calling an instance method on any object and calling it directly? 
For example:
>>> instance.run()
<class __main__.Instanza at 0x7f5b7b4c5f50>
>>> Instanza.run()
<__main__.Instanza instance at 0x7f5b7b4b3f70>

A:

It's a difference only syntactically.
The interpreter will treat any expression as if it were part of a class definition if it ends with a colon and a space. That is, as long as it contains no newlines or other whitespace.
>>> def foo(): pass
>>> import datetime
>>> foo = datetime.datetime.now
>>> class Bar:
...     a: int = 3
...
>>>
>>> foo()
>>> Bar.a
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
NameError: attribute lookup Bar on int failed
>>> 
>>> Bar.a
<bound method int.__get__ of <class 'datetime.datetime'>>
>>> foo.Bar.a
<bound method int.__get__ of <class 'datetime.datetime'>>
misinformation:
It's a difference only syntactically.
The interpreter will treat any expression as if it were part of a class definition if it ends with a colon and a space. That is, as long as it contains no newlines or other whitespace.

A new study by MIT physicists and their colleagues has shown that the human eye is exquisitely sensitive to a wide range of subtle sounds produced by the turbulent movement of water in the ears.

The research, which also included collaborators from the University of California, San Diego, suggests that humans are capable of detecting sounds made by a much larger range of vibrations — from the faintest of ripples in a pond to the roaring of a surf wave — than had been previously thought.

“It’s about a hundred times better than our senses, and it’s much higher sensitivity than previously thought possible,” says Markus Dahn, a professor of physics and physiology and engineering at MIT who led the research, which appears in the Jan. 27 issue of Physical Review Letters. The findings, he says, have “dramatic consequences for our understanding of auditory perception in humans,” in which sounds play a major role.

Dahn and his collaborators studied the effect of the water in the ear on waves of sound traveling through the eardrum made by a small vibrating object, which can produce a wide range of frequencies — from low, as in a whisper, to very high, as would be produced by a small airplane buzzing overhead.

Previous research has shown that a simple acoustic device, such as a loudspeaker, can only reproduce sounds within a very narrow band of frequencies — the range from about 20 to about 20,000 Hz. This is because the speaker’s “diaphragm” produces sound by vibrating at a certain frequency, and by design, can only produce sound within a very narrow frequency range of 20 to 20,000 Hz.

The MIT, UCSD and University of Washington research, led by physics and physiology professor David M. Caulfield, suggests that the human ear in fact detects sound waves with an effective bandwidth of about 20 to 200 Hz.

If a sound is slightly out of this range, the ear is able to tune to the frequency of a vibration that is related to the frequency of the original sound waves. This is what the ear is able to do in everyday situations when listening to a violin or a piano, for example. However, the system “is so good that for our study we were only able to tell the difference between a sound that was within the human audible range and one that was way above that,” Dahn explains.

Mental Health at Work: A Review of the Literature.
Work-related anxiety and illness are a significant health-affecting issues, particularly when they persist over time. The literature contains an abundance of studies on mental and physical illnesses associated with various occupations. This article explores mental health in the work setting. A bibliographic search was conducted on March 29-30, 2017, in the PubMed and Psycinfo databases, to retrieve articles focusing on mental health at work in the U.S. The term "mental health" was used, as well as the words "mental health," "work stress," and "occupational stress." All publications between 2011 and 2016 are explored, and the most important findings of each study are presented. The first part of this review considers a summary of studies that provide a perspective on the current state of the profession. An overview of the literature reveals that mental health continues to pose a significant issue for many occupations, which underscores the need to better understand work-related mental health in various professions.

The present invention relates generally to the fields of apoptosis and apoptosis detection. More particularly, it concerns the use of a caspase family inhibitor as a treatment and diagnostic agent for cancer.
2. Description of Related Art
Cancer is a major public health problem worldwide. A wide variety of treatment options have been developed for cancer over the last few decades, including surgery, radiotherapy and chemotherapy, e.g. see “Chemotherapy” In: Lippincott-Raven E R, Fischman R A (Eds): Scientific American Medicine, W. B. Saunders Company, Philadelphia, PA 1993, pp. 975-996.
Despite great advances in oncological treatment, the overall 5-year survival rate for patients with advanced or metastatic cancer remains dismal, ranging from 24% for gastric adenocarcinoma to a mere 4% for advanced or metastatic Hodgkin lymphoma. Additionally, the 5-year survival rate for some types of cancer is now reported to be less than 10%. Therefore, significant efforts have been directed towards the identification and validation of novel targeted therapies to improve survival rates in various cancers.
Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that plays an important role in a broad spectrum of physiologic and pathologic events ranging from embryonic development to tissue homeostasis, and has emerged as a potential therapeutic target in some human cancers (reviewed in Evan et al., 2005, Nature Rev. Cancer 2005, 5:258). Caspases are one group of proteases that function to trigger the characteristic features of apoptosis. There are 10 caspase genes in mammalian cells, as classified from sequence homologies: caspase-1 (interleukin-1 beta-converting enzyme (ICE)), caspase-2 (IL-1 β-converting enzyme 2), caspase-3 (CPP-32; Caspase-I), caspase-4, caspase-5, caspase-6, caspase-7 (DeltapI), caspase-8 (FLICE) and caspase-9 (CPP-30; Caspase-IV).

The present invention relates to a portable battery for electric shavers and the like.
Portable cells are currently known for the storage of alkaline batteries that are used in electric shavers.
A typical example is U.S. Pat. No. 5,822,539 that discloses a portable cell for electric shavers. A battery case consists of an upper and lower case including an internal cap for connection to an electric shaver.
One of the problems arising with the currently known known cells is the size of the battery. As electric shavers have been designed to be lighter and thinner, batteries have also reduced in size. This has particularly been the case for larger electric shavers. Hence, the available space for the storage of the battery becomes restricted.
Another problem with a battery such as defined in U.S. Pat. No. 5,822,539 is the safety. As such a case also includes an internal cap, the possibility to inadvertently remove it, for example when cleaning the shaver increases.
There is thus a need for a smaller battery that is safer by containing the battery in closed cases only, i.e., closed for all purposes.
There is also a need for such a battery that is more convenient to use, as it includes a more compact design than the currently existing shavers.
There is also a need for such a battery that has a size of the actual battery sufficient to handle the power requirements of electric shavers, but that has a reduced volume in relation to electric shavers of the same power.
According to an aspect of the present invention there is provided a battery comprising: a first case including a hollow first case half having an open face and a first closed side and a second case half including a hollow second case half having an open face and a second closed side and being attached to the hollow first half such that the open face of the hollow first half faces the open face of the hollow second case half, and containing an electrode, a conductive member and an insulating member; a second case attached to the open face of the first case half and to the open face of the second case half; a first terminal of the electrode attached to the second case; an electrode extension extended from at least one of the first and second case halves and having a first terminal attached to the first terminal of the first case half and a second terminal; and a second terminal attached to the second case.

Opinion: Time to Take a Stand on Immigration

Friday

May 30, 2017 at 12:22 PMMay 30, 2017 at 12:22 PM

Let’s stop the political grandstanding on the so-called sanctuary cities and get to the heart of immigration

By Chris Hill

This week, it seems the American conversation is stuck on immigration. Whether it be President Donald Trump or the liberal left, one side or the other always seems to be the issue of the week on Twitter and social media. Immigration is always an easy talking point for both liberal and conservative and is the perfect way to continue our political rhetoric. This week, it is sanctuary cities and the recent controversy following the killing of illegal immigrant Luis Viana in Chicago.

The mayor of that city, Rahm Emmanuel, is a liberal, so therefore that is where the liberal rhetoric started. Then Donald Trump chimed in with his tweet following the incident. The debate seems to turn on a constant question. Is illegal immigration a crime or is it victimless? Is it a public safety threat or does it contribute to the economy? This is a conversation that most people have, but we are all guilty of forgetting we need to separate the fact that we are a nation of laws, but we are also a nation of compassion.

It is important we remember that as politicians, we are all guilty. The issue of immigration is a complicated issue and is only ever going to have a simple solution. The solution is not going to be a quick Band-Aid. To solve issues like immigration or sanctuary cities we need to understand the system and the underlying problems, then we need to understand the impact that would have if we solved those problems. We need to think about the consequences and if they help us achieve what we aspire to as a country. One of these solutions is to change the way our government works. It might mean a fundamental change in our election system, our justice system and changing how the media works.

This is a huge step for everyone to consider, but in order to take that step it will be necessary for us to examine what solutions are appropriate. For the last two presidential elections I’ve stood by and cried when Donald Trump won, I cried for Hillary Clinton also, but I also cried for America. That is a feeling I don’t think the liberal left or the conservative right should have. We all should be Americans, even the ones who are not. It is time we got rid of

Bilateral pleural effusions as initial manifestations of sarcoidosis.
The prevalence and pathogenesis of bilateral pleural effusions in patients with sarcoidosis (bilateral pulmonary effusion and bilateral pleural effusions) are not known. A retrospective chart review was performed on patients who had both chest computed tomography (CT) and pulmonary function testing at the Cleveland Clinic. The frequency of bilateral effusions was determined, as was the presence of other known etiologies for pleural effusion on CT. Bilateral abnormalities were noted in 16 of 28 (57%) patients in whom there was a complete CT examination. The CT examination was abnormal in 17 of 25 (68%) patients with sarcoidosis and all 5 (100%) of the patients with known sarcoidosis and other primary pulmonary disease; 11 of 15 patients (73%) with clinically suspected sarcoidosis had sarcoidosis diagnosed by biopsy or clinical and radiographic findings. Among patients with sarcoidosis, the absence of other etiologies for bilateral effusions (10 of 15 patients) suggested that these effusions were probably secondary to a systemic disorder. The presence of bilateral pleural effusion during the initial phase of sarcoidosis suggests systemic disease and prompts a greater degree of suspicion for the presence of a concomitant lung disorder. Bilateral CT pleural findings, in spite of being a frequent manifestation of sarcoidosis, are often insufficient to warrant a diagnostic thoracentesis.

Semiconductor devices are extensively used in the electronics industry in many products such as televisions, computers, cellular phones, and memory devices to name just a few. Semiconductor devices typically exhibit a very high density of electrical components. In order to operate at high speed, this density of electrical components demands small feature sizes. Many advances in the fabrication of semiconductor device have attempted to satisfy this demand.
As feature sizes are reduced and device size are reduced, one of the more difficult problems that arise relates to interconnects. This is particularly true for smaller devices, such as mobile devices, which must have a robust interconnect system having reliability to be considered practical. In an integrated circuit, the fabrication of the semiconductor components and the conductor structures requires a sequence of processing steps to be effective. A common fabrication process for semiconductor components starts with a silicon substrate having a planar upper surface, and a layer of a dielectric material covering the substrate. Patterning the dielectric layer defines locations where openings will later be formed. Conductive material (that is, interconnect material) is subsequently deposited to fill the openings. This process is repeated until the desired number of interconnect levels have been constructed. The process is often referred to as interconnect fabrication.
In the fabrication of interconnects, a common approach used for forming the conductive feature of the interconnect is a damascene process. This process involves forming an etch stop layer using a plasma deposition technique before the etch stop layer is over etched to form holes and trenches. An amorphous silicon layer is often formed and partially planarized in damascene processing. However, the amorphous silicon layer must include certain dopants, which is not typically included in the amorphous silicon layer formed by an ASG process. It is not practical for a metal film to be deposited on amorphous silicon because it has been found that such a process causes the amorphous silicon to oxidize. An interface layer must therefore be created for example by the formation of an amorphous silicon oxide layer on the surface of a metal before deposition of the other materials, such as a metal film. Unfortunately, in the formation of such an amorphous silicon oxide layer, the oxygen tends to react with the metal, which forms an oxide that is not capable of further oxidation. This is a particularly damaging problem resulting from a reaction of metals with oxygen during deposition of the oxide. The surface of the metal becomes oxidized before a robust, electrically

[Morphofunctional and ultrastructural characteristics of the myocardium under the action of acetyl-1-formylimidamide in experimental infarct].
Morpho-functional and ultrastructural characteristics of rat myocardium under the action of acetyl-1-formylimidamide in vitro (an inhibitor of proteases) were studied in experimental acute myocardial infarct. The findings evidence that the course of the experimental acute myocardial infarct is conditioned by the disturbances of the heart metabolism as well as by the changes in the morphological and functional parameters of the myocardium. Treatment with acetyl-1-formylimidamide causes an increase of protein synthesis and reduces the lysosomal degradation. Administration of the drug contributes to an adequate compensation of the disturbances in the metabolic processes in the infarct area.

Q:

Why do we need the field homomorphisms of topological vector spaces to be continuous?

If we are talking about the homomorphisms $f : V \rightarrow W$ between two topological vector spaces $V$ and $W$, it's obvious that there is an issue. Some elements of $V$ may not be mapped onto elements of $W$ under a given continuous map (e. g. the homomorphism $f(x,y)=y-x$). Therefore, I think, homomorphisms between general topological vector spaces can either be defined to be continuous, or continuous only if certain subsets don't contribute to the image.
Thus, if I get the homomorphism right with respect to that the image cannot depend on the homomorphism, we can just assume the homomorphisms be continuous automatically. Is this correct? I am not familiar with field homomorphisms of topological vector spaces in literature, so I don't know if this is the case.

A:

This is right. This is a very good point that you make and so that is what I will assume. 
Now you state that there are certain sets of $V$ which don't contribute to the image of the homomorphism. 
If you are allowed to make your definition of a homomorphism independent of your definition of continuity you will likely get away with $S_1$ and $S_2$ and so your question doesn't arise. 
In a setting where there is a natural topology on $V$ and the homomorphism is required to be continuous as a map between topological spaces you will have to do some reasoning on what you may be able to omit. Such reasoning however may be subtle. An example of a setting where the setting of discontinuities will be a concern for you is in the field setting where the homomorphic fields are also supposed to be complete in addition to the topology (for the reason which you already stated). Then of course all the field elements will give continuous functions as soon as you fix a topology.
That said I think your basic point has merit.

Q:

Couchbase Server CouchDB Query

I'm new to Couchbase and CouchDB.  I'd like to get some help with the following requirements:
I have a client app that will be used to create a document in CouchDB every hour.
I need to have the client app only create documents, and have no idea, the most simplistic explanation I can think of would be "if the document already exists, don't do anything". This is why I know I need CouchDB.
I was reading this in the online CouchDB Manual, "Insert or overwrite documents if newer/bigger".

This is where I need help.  If I was to have my client app store it's documents into CouchDB and then periodically hit a CouchbaseServer URL to query CouchDB for all of the documents in CouchDB, does that mean that CouchbaseServer wouldn't be involved in that query, and instead CouchDB would be doing it?  I need some expert input on all of this, or at least clarification on the CouchDB part.  Thanks for the help!

A:

In your request body you can just update one parameter if the document is not exist and use HTTP ETAG to update the document, this will cause couchbase to return a 304 not modified HTTP response.  Using this method will save you a round-trip to couchbase because you will end up with the right data.
GET /db/_all_docs?include_docs=true

PUT /db/doc1 HTTP/1.1

If-Match:"1"

ETag:33

GET /db/_all_docs?include_docs=true

With the query to couchbase just update the existing doc
It would be more complex to support a delete and update, but to delete you would delete the doc in couchbase and then couchbase wouldn't be aware of that until the next update of the document, which can probably be done too.  To update you would have to do 1 of 2 things, delete the document and then insert the new content or update the content of the document in couchbase.

The first aim of this review is to determine how well the various new techniques have been validated to assess the quality of care. It is unlikely that the results of new studies will be directly applicable to studies assessing the quality of care, and the second aim is to present the evidence in a systematic way on the extent to which the new techniques are needed to assess the quality of care.

Research has shown that high-quality trials are used far less often as a source of evidence than are less-high-quality trials on a similar topic.[@CR47]^,^[@CR96]^--^[@CR100] It is therefore essential that we improve the quality of research if we are to maximize its relevance to policymaking.

Research on the quality of care is often criticized for focusing on a small sample of patients or a single episode of care.[@CR101]^--^[@CR103] However, research studies of this nature provide important data on the quality of care as it is experienced by patients. Given the high prevalence and chronicity of the disease and a large gap in knowledge, research is very timely and important.[@CR104]^,^[@CR105] We included studies that included any kind of intervention or care, and we are confident that most of the studies addressed a generalizable population.

Limitations of the Systematic Review {#Sec16}
-----------------------------------

Many studies are published with no peer review, which means that our review is at risk of excluding research that might have been useful. However, the review team checked the citations of the eligible papers before entering the full-text data. Only studies reporting quantitative data, such as study-level numbers and measures of accuracy or precision, were entered. We chose to exclude studies in areas such as social sciences and qualitative research, where no standard quality assessment tools are available and we lack the skills to critically appraise the quality of studies. Studies not in English were excluded. This excludes all studies from LMICs.

The search strategy was designed to find articles focusing on either the quality of care or the use of CPGs. We excluded articles that simply discuss the value of CPGs, but do not examine quality of care. It would be useful to know both where CPGs are needed and where additional research is urgently needed. 1. Field of the Invention
The present invention relates to the use of polyalkylene oxide-containing graft copolymers with sterically hindered phenolic resins and o-alkylstyrene copolymers for improving stabilization which protects the resins and elastomeric compositions against thermal degradation.
2. Description of Prior Art
Many phenolic resins are stabilized with phenolic resins by the combination of a phenolic resin and a copolymer derived from a diene monomer.
The phenolic resins are used alone or in combination with a variety of unsaturated monomers to provide a variety of useful products, such as butadiene-based rubbers, phenolic resins, phenolic novolakyne resins, and urethane resins. The butadiene-based rubbers are used alone or in combination with other resins, e.g., rubbers, tackifying resins, and elastomeric copolymers. Phenolic novolakyne resins are used in combination with isoprene rubber and other rubbers for providing good weatherproofing and antistatic properties, such as disclosed in U.S. Pat. No. 4,374,240.
An important parameter used to determine the effectiveness of stabilizing additives, such as polyalkylene oxide-containing graft copolymers, with phenolic resin for styrene/unsaturated monomer copolymers, is the induction period that is measured when samples of the polymer are placed in ovens at specific temperatures for periods of time. The induction period indicates the amount of time necessary for the phenolic resin to degrade to a certain level and is measured in degrees of stabilization.
The induction period should remain less than about 90 minutes at 210.degree. F. for a satisfactory level of stabilization. The stabilization should preferably be carried out over a temperature range of about 0.degree. to about 340.degree. F. The copolymer of a diene monomer and an unsaturated monomer, which is employed, can be, for example, an o-alkylstyrene copolymer, an isomonoolefin copolymer, an isobutylene/isoprene copolymer, a hydrocarbon copolymer, an alkyl acrylate copolymer, a vinyl chloride/vinyl acetate copolymer, a diene terpolymer, a diene block copolymer, polyisoprene or polybutadi

Predictive value of perioperative plasma and tissue glucose levels for the development of early postoperative metabolic dysfunction in children undergoing non-cardiac surgery.
Postoperative metabolic dysfunction (MOD) following non-cardiac surgery remains a frequent complication of surgical treatment in pediatric patients. It is associated with increased risk of perioperative cardiorespiratory complications and, in the long term, with adverse outcomes. We compared the predictive value of perioperative plasma and tissue glucose levels for MOD in pediatric patients receiving surgery for repair of congenital heart disease, urinary tract anomalies, or other intraabdominal or lower extremity malformations. Our hypothesis was that the perioperative levels of both plasma and tissue glucose could predict the development of MOD in these patients. Using data from a prospective study conducted in the Pediatric Surgery Intensive Care Unit (ICU) of a tertiary-care children's hospital between 2005 and 2010, we studied the relationship between the preoperative and intraoperative levels of plasma and tissue glucose and MOD in 30 surgical patients (median age 6 mo, range 1-23 mo). MOD was present in 73% of all patients. A positive association was found between an intraoperative plasma glucose level of ≥ 10mmol/L and the occurrence of MOD on Day 1 [odds ratio 4.29; 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.28-14.48; p = 0.019] and Days 2-4 (odds ratio 9.64; 95% CI 2.16-42.55; p = 0.003). An intraoperative tissue glucose level of ≥ 10 mmol/g predicted the occurrence of MOD on Day 1 (odds ratio 2.54; 95% CI 1.23-5.24; p = 0.01) and on Day 2-4 (odds ratio 6.08; 95% CI 2.27-16.29; p < 0.001). The preoperative level of tissue glucose (p = 0.025) as well as the decrease in tissue glucose levels (p = 0.035) over the first week postoperatively correlated positively with the MOD score at Day 7. Our study highlights the importance of tissue glucose levels, measured intraoperatively, for the prediction of MOD after surgery in pediatric patients.

The difference between a good and a great work is that the great work has its own definition on its own.

It has become a common theme in many writings, that when asked this question the one and only answer could come be that “the great work is something that has no definition.”

When this happens, it is as if there is a question begging for attention to the side effect that this answer is very common, yet it still is an untrue answer, which leads us to look at the definition more closely, and perhaps we need to define the great work before we can make a conclusion.

Therefore it is my belief there is not so much a difference between a good and a great work. Instead we need to look at the definitions themselves.

So when we consider work done by a person as being good or great, it is based on certain standards. This can be because of the amount of work produced, or the level of skill and abilities of the person at their craft.

But as the amount of work produced or level of skill is something that we are likely to compare many things with. Is this to say then that in a specific example, we can never compare a master craftsman, or a person of average skill to a master engineer.

This answer can be considered an out of touch statement as well, as it is an obvious truth that, an engineer or work of art like say a clock or sculpture is of no comparison to a person’s skill.

This brings us back to looking at the definitions, and what the standards are and what the goals set will be.

It should be noted, that this will also apply to the standards of a people and culture, since a nation will likely be formed from the set of standards of the people.

We are talking about things that are of the highest quality and standards. We are talking about a great works of art, or a great piece of music, or a great sculpture.

[The effect of high doses of thyroxine in hypothyroidism and the role of thyrotropic hormone (author's transl)].
Experiments were carried out on five patients (two male, three female, mean age: 65, mean dose: 16.2 mcg/kg/day) with hypothyroidism caused by diffuse disease. In the first three patients the effect that high serum levels of T4 and T3 had on the thyroid function was studied before and after increasing the doses of thyroxine in order to normalize these levels (up to 100 mcg/dl T4 and up to 12.5 mcg/dl T3). A significant increase in T3 concentrations was noted, with some signs of thyroid activation despite the apparent normalization of the serum concentrations of the three hormones and the disappearance of TSH after a mean of 8 weeks of treatment. The two other patients, on the contrary, had subclinical hypothyroid disease with normal T3 and T4 serum concentrations. After a mean of two weeks during which a very significant decrease in serum TSH had been observed, treatment with thyroxine was resumed with a mean dose of 18 mcg/kg/week. In this group no modifications could be perceived in the clinical evolution.

This application claims the priority of German Patent Document 103 31 692.2, filed Jul. 24, 2003, the disclosure of which is expressly incorporated by reference herein.
The invention relates to a device and a corresponding method for the preparation of a mixture containing at least two substances which are stored in at least two separate containers.
In order to be able to work in safety, there is an ever growing trend to provide technical systems which require only minimum operating staff. Moreover, it is very frequently desired to be able to configure, for example, the mixing of different substances to be present only a single unit to carry out such a process.
German Patent Document DE-A-3,904,626 discloses a solution for the preparation of a mixture. According to that patent, a mixture is stored in a liquid vessel. A piston which is arranged in the liquid vessel in a freely movably manner is provided with a mixer which is in the form of a scraper conveyor. The piston is provided with recesses in the form of a channel. In addition, the piston is equipped with a mixing element at the outlet of the channel. This mixing element produces a pressure wave in the liquid being mixed so that it is possible to work in safety without any particular problem. Due to its specific construction, however, that solution is unsuitable for the use in an office automation device for the preparation of a mixture which requires only a small number of operating personnel.
It is therefore an object of the invention to develop a device and a corresponding method for the preparation of a mixture which is suitable in particular for office use.
This object is achieved with a device in accordance with the invention wherein the mixing element is a simple valve which is connected fixedly to a mixing tube. It is therefore possible to prepare a mixture using the described device from the fixedly connected mixing tube so that it is possible to have the same mixture which is ready at any desired time.
In addition, the valve is designed in a very simple manner, so that it can be used particularly in an office automation device which has a small physical design.
An especially preferred embodiment of this connection is achieved by the valve being made of plastic, with the mixing tube being arranged as a rigid part in a groove of the valve and the valve, including the mixing tube mounted in a casing provided with the groove. Through its simple design, this embodiment has an especially small physical size, and it is very well usable, for example for a cartridge-type device.

[Fever of unknown origin, unusual for malaria].
The authors present five cases of fever of unknown origin in a five-year period at the Department of internal medicine at the University Hospital in Lund. The clinical course and laboratory investigations, excluding the most obvious causes of infection, as well as the diagnostic procedures are summarized. The aetiology of the fever is unknown in 4 of the patients, of whom 2 had fever of unknown origin, but the aetiology was suspected to be of infective origin, based on a prolonged fever, previous history of disease and laboratory findings. The third patient had suspected malaria, though no parasites were found, no diagnosis was made and the final diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma was discovered 3 1/2 years later. In the fifth case, the diagnosis was an undifferentiated pleural tumour. Fever of unknown origin represents a diagnostic and therapeutic challenge, since a prolonged disease may be the expression of a tumour or of immunologic or infectious disease. Therefore, thorough diagnostic work-up is mandatory.

The present invention relates to water-in-oil emulsion and sprayable polymer compositions. More particularly, the present invention relates to water-in-oil emulsion and sprayable polymer compositions such as polyaspartamide which are particularly adapted for use on or in agricultural crops as protective and/or growth enhancing agents.
Various polymeric emulsions have been developed which are sprayable. These emulsions are typically water-in-oil emulsions which are formed by mixing and emulsifying various polymeric resins with water in an aqueous emulsifier or surfactant. The combination of emulsifier and resin is, however, typically not stable at high shear rates nor is it sufficiently stable for high speed production of large volumes of sprayable coatings on farms. Additionally, it is often very difficult to spray these emulsions onto agricultural crops.
Further, many commercially available resin compositions have low viscosity characteristics which make these resin compositions highly susceptible as coating dispersions. In addition, the resin compositions are not particularly sprayable.
Thus, a need exists for sprayable emulsions including one or more polymeric resins which are thermally and/or radiation stable, have an acceptable viscosity, are easy to apply and are effective for protecting agricultural crops against insects such as insects and/or diseases.
Thus, the present invention relates to novel sprayable emulsion and resin compositions which meet the need outlined above. More particularly, the present invention relates to water-in-oil emulsion and sprayable polymer compositions comprising at least about 40% by weight of a water-in-oil emulsion resin having a solids content of about 15% to about 30% by weight of solid matter, more preferably between about 16% and 29% by weight of solid matter, a solids/water ratio of from between about 1.3:1 and about 2.5:1, and a pH less than about 8.0.
The novel sprayable emulsions contain the polyaspartamide composition of the present invention as a polymer. These sprayable emulsions also contain a water-in-oil emulsifying agent. The emulsifying agent is most preferably an emulsifying or emulsion modifying agent. These emulsions contain the water-in-oil emulsion resin, the emulsifier, surfactant and water. The addition of these components is essential to the effectiveness of the emulsion for protecting agricultural crops.

It sounds like your code is not being compiled for Android. By default an Android application has android:name=".MainActivity".
You'll need to add an appropriate AndroidManifest.xml file with the appropriate activity declaration:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>

Surgical Treatment for Acromio-clavicular Dislocation: Technique and Results.
In order to develop a standard treatment protocol, to report short and long term outcome of surgery for acromio-clavicular (AC) dislocation and to provide evidence for the need for arthroscopic surgery. From 2001 to 2007, 26 out of 33 patients with acute AC dislocation were operated on in the Urological department of a level III trauma center. Three patients with chronic AC dislocation were treated arthroscopically. Patients with associated injuries including clavicle and axillary fracture/dislocation, brachial plexus injury and acute trauma cases were included. The mean followup time was 22 months (range: 12-44) and 12 months (range: 3-12) for arthroscopic and open surgical interventions respectively. The mean age was 29 (range: 19-42) years. Eighteen out of 26 patients had previous trauma to the shoulder joint. All patients complained of shoulder pain on history. Three patients had mild shoulder pain after trauma while the other 23 patients had anterior shoulder pain which was aggravated during abduction and resisted abduction maneuvers such as throwing a ball or swimming. There were no associated clavicle or axillary fracture/dislocations. The mean Constant score was 85 (range: 0-100) before surgery and improved to 90 (range: 0-100) after surgery. For arthroscopic surgery (7 patients), mean Constant score improved from 69 to 88 post surgery; while for open surgery (10 patients), mean Constant score improved from 91 to 98. Ten patients, who had previous trauma before the surgery and 10 patients, who had no history of trauma before the surgery, had the same operative technique, the former were reoperated for arthroscopy while the latter for open surgery. Patients who had no history of trauma were operated for open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF). The average time gap between the trauma and surgery was 2 weeks. Seven patients had residual pain and reduced active motion. All patients had good functional outcomes based on the constant score improvement and excellent patient satisfaction. There is a strong need to develop a more effective method to treat AC dislocation effectively and that arthroscopy is less invasive and more appropriate than open surgery for patients with AC dislocation. Level IV: Therapeutic study, retrospective study.

How to find the average of the largest values in a dictionary?

How can I get the average of the 'largest' values in the dictionary given below?
In the following dictionary, I am only interested in finding the average of the values that are sorted in descending order.
{'A': 10, 'B': 20, 'C': 30, 'X': 50, 'Y': 60, 'Z': 70}

How would I do?

A:

>>> {'A': 10, 'B': 20, 'C': 30, 'X': 50, 'Y': 60, 'Z': 70}
{'Z': 70,
 'B': 20,
 'C': 30,
 'A': 10,
 'Y': 60,
 'X': 50}
>>> sorted_dict = { v: k for k, v in sorted_dict.items() }
>>> {i/len(sorted_dict): i for i in sorted_dict}
{'Z': 70,
 'B': 20,
 'C': 30,
 'A': 10,
 'Y': 60}
>>> print(list(sorted_dict))
[30, 20, 70, 10, 60]
>>> float(sum(sorted_dict)) / len(sorted_dict)
20.0

A:

This could work for you, assuming that you don't need the keys of the dictionary.
values = sorted(d.values(), key=lambda k:d[k], reverse=True)[:6]

Now, the first line simply sorts the values, based on the key provided in reverse mode. This makes the values sorted in descending order.
The second step takes 6 values from that sorted list.

Hemodynamic effects of the calcium entry blocker felodipin in the intact dog.
We sought to determine if felodipin (an analog of nifedipine) could alter cardiovascular function in the intact animal and to compare its effects to those of verapamil (a conventional calcium entry blocker). In anesthetized dogs, felodipine (10, 20, 40, and 80 mg/kg i.v.) caused dose-dependent decreases in systemic arterial, pulmonary artery, and left atrial pressures and arterial blood pressure without altering heart rate. The effects of felodipin (40 mg/kg) were qualitatively similar to those of verapamil (1.2 mg/kg). The duration of action of felodipin (40 mg/kg) was greater than or equal to 5 minutes in three of four dogs and as long as 50 minutes in the fourth, whereas verapamil (1.2 mg/kg) decreased systemic arterial pressure and atrial blood pressure and increased arterial pressure and heart rate for at least 1 and 10 minutes, respectively. The hemolytic action of felodipin was significantly lower than that of verapamil (1.2 mg/kg). The cardiovascular activity of felodipin demonstrated in the intact anesthetized dog is qualitatively similar to that of verapamil. The lower hemolytic activity of felodipin may confer a greater therapeutic index than that observed with verapamil.

Anaerobic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid via two consecutive dechlorination by Clostridium sticklandii K11.
2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) and its congeners are widely used for selective herbicide in agricultural practices and are often detected as an environmental contaminant of groundwater. 2,4-D was transformed by the Gram-positive bacterium Clostridium sp. K11 in batch anaerobic cultures with ethanol as electron donor. 2,4-D was dechlorinated to 2,3-dichlorophenol (2,3-D) as the main product via a first step, which was followed by a dechlorination of 2,3-D to 3-chloropropionic acid (3-CAPA) from a second step. A transient 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) by-product formed during the first dechlorination step. The intermediates 2,3,6,7-TCDD and 2,3,7,8,9-TCDD were identified as breakdown products of the TCDD by-product, indicating degradation by a TCDD dehalogenase. C. sticklandii K11 was isolated in pure culture from groundwater, where 2,4-D was detected, and was capable of degrading 2,4-D at concentration of 1 mg/L in liquid synthetic medium with ethanol as electron donor. Isolated strains from the 2,4-D degraders showed similar enzymatic activities and dechlorination pattern as well as similar DNA-DNA relatedness to the original isolates. 2,4-D was dechlorinated by C. sticklandii K11, in contrast to Pseudomonas natriigens DSM 17893, which was isolated from an anoxic aquifer with 2,4-D and did not dechlorinate 2,4-D.

Cannot access my app on Play Store

This might be a stupid question. I searched a lot, but I still don't really get it. The question is simple.
I made a new project in Eclipse + Android SDK and got everything working. I made a new project in an empty Android Studio and did some changes. I uploaded the APK to Google Play and it was accepted. Then I made some other changes in the project and uploaded the APK agian. Google Play rejected the APK!
Google Play says:

MyApp App can't be installed on your device, as it contains APK which are either not supported or the signature does not match.

When I look into the app details, I can see that Play Store downloaded the new APK, but it doesn't install the application. What can I do?

A:

Do you have access to your computer and the Google Play Console? If everything goes well with you in the last update, you could use the option "Generate Signed APK...", and the apk downloaded by Play Store will be signed.
In addition, when you upload it through Google, the apk must be uploaded with the same Bundle ID as your app in the developer console. Check that this Bundle ID is the same in the app details of your app in the Developer center.
Finally, you can try to delete the previous apk and upload again, and it will overwrite it.
Hope it helps you.
