Nucleoli and centromeres are associated in two distinct forms of mitotic centromere-nucleolus association in Drosophila melanogaster.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the chromosomes contain the centromeres that are attached to the mitotic spindle and centrosomes during cell division. In most cell types, centromeric regions of chromosomes are always located at the center of the nucleus and at the boundary of the nucleoli. Thus, a mitotic centromere-nucleolus association is normally observed. However, we report here that a mitotic centromeres-nucleolus association is induced in larval salivary gland polytene chromosomes at the first mitotic division and a nucleolus is never associated with the centromere of chromosomes. Our results suggest that the centrosome, one of the major nucleating centers, might be excluded from the mitotic centromeres-nucleolus association when the centromeres initiate mitotic spindle attachment to the chromosomes. Two types of centromere-nucleolus associations, "spindle-attached" and "spindle-independent types", were identified by their different mechanisms of initiation through mitotic spindle attachment. The formation of type I centromere-nucleolus association involves the spindle attachment to chromosomes and the nucleolus and centromere are associated in one chromatid. On the other hand, the formation of type II centromere-nucleolus association does not require mitotic spindle attachment and the centromere and nucleolus associate in both of chromatids.

Is the following algorithm an example of a Divide and Conquer algorithm or not?

Algorithm is supposed to be a divide and conquer algorithm for some NP-Complete problem. It doesn't really meet the divide and conquer definition - it requires exponential (actually power) blowup for large input. For example there can't be smaller set of smaller subsets (e.g. {0}, {1, 0}, {0, 1},..., {0, 1, 0},...) as the divide and conquer operation would fail to work correctly, as we are dividing a very small subset of a larger one. 
Is that an example of a divide and conquer, or it's not, as it doesn't meet all of "all steps of the Algorithm must be in P" or "further subgroups must be in P (as in the initial part of the Algorithm)"?

A:

Consider the function
$$f(x) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if } x \text{ is a square}\\ 0, &\text{otherwise} \end{cases}$$
Your question would be equivalent to asking whether 
$$f_n(k) = \sum\limits_{f_{n-1}(l) = 1} 2^{k(n+1) - l^n}$$ 
is a polynomial time algorithm (in $n$) for $f$. We have $f_1(x) = x$ and $f_n = (1 + 2x^n)(1+x+...+x^n) - x^{n+1}$. Plugging the first two values, we see that $f_2(k) = 1 + 2^k(2^{k(k-1)}+\cdots+5+1)$. This is already very far from being a polynomial time algorithm in $n$; clearly, $f_n$ is a polynomial time algorithm for $f$.

The most frequent genetic cause of premature aging is Werner syndrome, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the human telomerase catalytic subunit-encoding gene at chromosome region 8p12. To investigate Werner syndrome pathogenesis, we isolated human primary fibroblasts from Werner patients and compared the cellular phenotype in fibroblasts from Werner syndrome patients and control human primary fibroblasts. The telomerase activity in fibroblasts at different passage numbers of cultures was significantly lower in human primary fibroblasts from Werner syndrome patients than those from control subjects. There were no significant differences in apoptosis and senescence markers between control and Werner cells. The expression levels of senescence-associated β-galactosidase and cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2 were also similar on passage 12 in control and Werner primary fibroblasts. In contrast, the expression levels of β-galactosidase in primary fibroblasts from Werner patients were strikingly increased on passage 4 (1.2-fold) and passage 8 (1.5-fold) compared with control cells. The expression of p21/CIP1 (WAF1/CIP1) and other telomere-protecting proteins, such as Ku70/86, was similar on passage 12 in control and Werner primary fibroblasts. p16/INK4A expression was lower in Werner primary fibroblasts than in control cells but not sufficient to explain their telomere dysfunction. Immuno-FISH assay also showed that the mean telomere length of chromosomal ends was shorter in Werner fibroblasts than in control fibroblasts. Moreover, we successfully obtained p16/INK4A null cells after gene targeting mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells and generated a p16/INK4A KO mouse model. Werner-1 and p16/INK4A KO cells exhibited similar cell proliferation compared with wt cells. I did a review on the B-25M at my local AAR in early 2004, but it wasn't put online for a few days after. There is now another review up under the same name at Aviation.info (which I contributed to and started).

The B-25 appears to be another of those old WW II "aircraft-of-opportunity" designs that didn't get that much attention when it was new. I think it had more press coverage when an RAF unit was assigned to the B-25 than in the USA, and I suspect that many of the folks involved with the B-25 were also from the RAF.

The B-25 did have its share of problems, as did all the postwar bombers. However, the B-25 came into service well ahead of any of the new generation designs that followed. I have always had a hard time with the P-51, so perhaps that was the aircraft I have the largest soft spot for. The B-25 had nothing special to stand on top of and no technology that was new and it had no high tech "bellyful of tricks" like that which was found in the P-51.

A few of the B-25M's had quite a number of problems. I remember one that had electrical problems requiring the pilot to be able to do the emergency power plant feat when he had to ditch. This aircraft eventually ended up in an air show as a prop conversion.

Even in the late 1990's, the B-25 still had a fan following in the UK. The B-25 has its enthusiasts as much as the Spitfire and the Vampire. I have some B-25s in my collection I bought because I saw them displayed on US TV shows or saw them at air shows.

In his original B-25M, the designer called it a "Bolt Thrower Killer", but it is now a lot more comfortable and roomy than the original design ever was. Since it replaced the B-24s as the USA's primary strategic airforce bomber of WW2, the B-25M was designed to be as comfortable as it could possibly be. It is not for people who love flying tight clearances, cramped quarters or flying very low. There really isn't anything else like the B-25M for a WWII collector.

This invention relates to automatic washes such as machines available from the Gillette Company of Gillette, S.D. and from the Carter Company of Chicago, Ill. that can be used for automatic washes of clothes. More particularly this invention relates to an automatic washer of the Gillette "Home Comfort" type that includes within it washing compartments through which the clothes are transported with the washing liquid pumped therein to perform the automatic wash operation.
2. State of the Prior Art
It has been well known in the prior art to provide clothes washing devices having a series of washing compartments with an apparatus that is driven in a predetermined operation of the compartments. A primary problem with compartments of this type is that the clothes are subject to mechanical deterioration.
U.S. Pat. No. 3,788,017 is illustrative of the prior art of compartments for clothes washing that is mechanical in operation.
A further problem with the prior art is that clothes are subject to mechanical deterioration due to the mechanical operation involved with the prior art washing machines.

Anatoly Tarasov

Anatoly Vladimirovich Tarasov (; born 10 November 1956) is a former Belarusian biathlete who competed between 1979 and 1984. He won three medals in the 3.5 km sprint and two gold medals in the 4 km mass start. He placed eighth in the 10 km pursuit. As an assistant master, he helped train athletes for two Olympic teams to the 2000 Summer Olympics in Salt Lake City.

Tarasov is married with three children

The invention relates to a multi-piece, water-jacketed press section of a hot-melt, adhesive-applied web-making machine, and to a hot-melt, adhesive-applied web-making machine comprising such press section.
Hot-melt, adhesive-applied web-making machines, such as that described in U.S. Pat. No. 4,681,402, the disclosure of which is incorporated herein by reference, enable the production of, e.g., wallpaper. In this apparatus, a pattern of an aqueous film-forming composition is applied to a web by a doctor blade, a rotary print wheel or the like, a carrier web is formed in contact with the treated web, the two webs are then passed through a nip between rolls and the aqueous film-forming composition is caused to melt by contact with the hot rolls and a pattern printed on the surface of the aqueous film, which includes the applied pattern. The printing is often done in accordance with a color-change in the film-forming composition, which makes it possible to realize a range of different colors in the printed pattern.
When printing the patterns in a multicolor, hot-melt, adhesive-applied wallpaper machine, it is required that the printed areas remain clear and transparent to the eye throughout the duration of use. To achieve this, it is important that the film-forming composition remains uniformly bonded to the carrier web throughout the production sequence.

More specifically, an ideal temperature profile in the nip for hot-melt, adhesive-applied wallpaper machines in the printing process is a temperature profile that will cause a constant increase of temperature in the nip from the web side to the carrier web side. Does using a library for networking help with performance?

We are building an application right now that communicates with an online 3rd party server. We are just starting to write the code now, and would rather not have to do all of the SSL stuff.
Since we are a small company, and I have relatively little experience with C#, I would rather use an external library (like an open source version of what IIS uses internally) to make this process very simple.
Would this be helpful? Any downsides? Is a library similar to a database in the sense that it improves performance? 

A:

Using an external library will definitely allow you to get started faster than if you had to implement it yourself, however:

You'll need to ensure you are referencing the correct version of the library by checking the Version number.
You'll likely need to update the library frequently as you learn/read about new SSL best practices to ensure it remains secure.
Libraries/APIs are usually proprietary, so may not support future versions of.Net Framework.
You'll still be implementing your network security (SSL, etc.).

Using an external library may be a smart choice, but you may want to consider the cost of not learning all these other components when using a library, specifically as you get further into your application.

A:

Using a library for networking is a bad idea. If performance is your aim, go about implementing it yourself instead.
There are many SSL/TLS libraries out there, but only a few that can do the work efficiently. For one reason or another, these libraries tend to be very "closed". If the development team for that particular software has made a bad decision, you'll be out of luck when that decision needs to be changed.
If you want to continue using a library, you're better off writing the code yourself than using an external library.

The present invention relates generally to the field of corn breeding. In particular, the invention relates to corn seed and plants of the variety designated CV556813, and derivatives and tissue cultures thereof.
2. Description of Related Art
The goal of field crop breeding is to combine various desirable traits in a single variety/hybrid. Such desirable traits include greater yield, better stalks, better roots, resistance to insecticides, herbicides, pests, and disease, tolerance to heat and drought, reduced time to crop maturity, better agronomic quality, higher nutritional value, and uniformity in germination times, stand establishment, growth rate, maturity, and fruit size.
Breeding techniques take advantage of a plant's method of pollination. There are two general methods of pollination: a plant self-pollinates if pollen from one flower is transferred to the same or another flower of the same plant. A plant cross-pollinates if pollen comes to it from a flower on a different plant.
Corn plants (Zea mays L.) can be bred by both self-pollination and cross-pollination. Both types of pollination involve the corn plant's flowers. Corn has separate male and female flowers on the same plant, located on the tassel and the ear, respectively. Natural pollination occurs in corn when wind blows pollen from the tassels to the silks that protrude from the tops of the ear shoot.
Plants that have been self-pollinated and selected for type over many generations become homozygous at almost all gene loci and produce a uniform population of true breeding progeny, a homozygous plant. A cross between two such homozygous plants produces a uniform population of hybrid plants that are heterozygous for many gene loci. Conversely, a cross of two plants each heterozygous at a number of loci produces a population of hybrid plants that differ genetically and are not uniform. The resulting non-uniformity makes performance unpredictable.
The development of uniform corn plant hybrids requires the development of homozygous inbred plants, the crossing of these inbred plants, and the evaluation of the crosses. Pedigree breeding and recurrent selection are examples of breeding methods used to develop hybrid parent plants from breeding populations. Those breeding methods combine the genetic backgrounds from two or more inbred plants or various other broad-based sources into breeding pools from which new inbred plants are developed by selfing and selection of desired phenotypes. Is this an example of an infinito cardinal?

According to wikipedia:

An infinite cardinal κ is a cardinal having no upper bound; i.e.,
   α < κ ≡ (α < κ ≤ κ). 
An infinite cardinal κ is said to be a proper cardinal if κ >
  κ + κ. A cardinal κ is said to be a weakly compact cardinal if κ >
  ℵω.

So, my question is: Does the cardinals in this picture

count as "infinite" and therefore qualify as infinito cardinal?

A:

Yes, and no. In the same sense that every real number is, not only not infinitary, but even not finitary, so is every infinite cardinal. They are real numbers greater than any real number. No such infinitary number is itself a natural number (e.g. not $12$ or even $7$, but something like $7.1$). However, many other real numbers are, including infinitary cardinals (though most are not particularly weakly compact). You might like to look to the section on “Natural and Infinitary Cardinal Numbers” in this article.
If we accept that the continuum is a weakly compact infinite cardinal, then the same argument shows that the continuum has the same status as every real number greater than $0$ and less than $1$, since any real number greater than $0$ and less than $1$ is greater than some infinite cardinal. If we accept that the continuum is an infinitary infinite cardinal, then we can do the same thing but with the Continuum Hypothesis.

Nathaniel Woodrow Wilson

Nathaniel Wilson (April 25, 1821, in Nanticoke, New York – July 5, 1870) was an American physician, educator, abolitionist and suffragist best known as the inventor of modern anesthesia. He was also the founder of Woodrow Wilson Medical School and first chairman of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation.

Life and career
Nathaniel Woodrow Wilson was the child of a Presbyterian minister and the son of a farmer; he received his liberal arts and medicine training through the assistance of his father. Upon graduating from New York Medical College in 1843 he entered a medical practice in Kingston, where he soon became interested in the care of women. He then set up what was then the first practical surgical ward, and in 1849 published a report on obstetric practice that would later be a standard textbook.

In 1852 Wilson moved to Chicago to establish a free clinic and free dispensary and to lecture on surgery and other subjects on the reform of medical education, a cause his father had been devoted to at home. By 1854 the operation of the clinic was successful and it became known to the medical establishment as the "Maternity and Infant Home". That same year Wilson published one of the first serious books on a subject to come under the term "hygiene". He was then able to interest his friends in the suffrage movement, and when Horace Greeley became the proprietor of the New-York Tribune, Wilson was appointed as his private sanitary advisor. He became increasingly interested in the new profession of journalism and in 1865 began to engage in it as a profession.

Wilson became increasingly enmeshed with the women's suffrage movement as it gained steam during the 1870s, and in 1870 he began to campaign that women should be allowed to vote. When a delegation of suffrage advocates arrived in Washington, D.C. seeking support, he wrote an essay on their causes which was published in several popular newspapers. They then met with President Ulysses S. Grant, who assured them of an official White House statement in their favor, and the passage of the Susan B. Anthony National Suffrage Bill the next year. Wilson was a member of the National WCTU and actively participated in its campaigns.

As public interest in sanitary sanitation increased, Wilson began to spend more time devising practical answers to problems. His work in public health was recognized during the late 1860s and early 1870s, and Wilson had become a popular

Does 'and' work with multiple 'or' conditions within the same expression?

For example:
SELECT *
FROM myTable
WHERE myCol in ('A', 'B')
  and myCol2 ='someValue'

And what about this?
SELECT *
FROM myTable
WHERE myCol ='someValue'
  or myCol2 ='someValue'

Obviously, none of the above queries will work, but am I correct in that the first one should?

A:

In SQL, the order of evaluation of predicates is important. This means that the first condition is evaluated first, then the second. The second condition will never be evaluated if the first returns false.
(In other words, this doesn't work:
WHERE myCol = 5
OR myCol = 10

That is why there are other operations like OR with UNION, or OR with EXCEPT.)
Because in an SQL WHERE clause, the OR operator has higher precedence than any comparison operators, your second query does not do what you think it does.
What would make the most sense to you?
WHERE  myCol ='someValue' OR myCol2 ='someValue'

If either of the values you expect to come back are missing in the column, your query will return false. Therefore, it will return data for anything that has either a value of'someValue'; it will not be able to tell you what the value of the column was, however.
To answer your question:

I'm actually aware of that, but in my case I just want some things to be true and some false, but to not be equal. Something like:
where(col = val) and (col2 == val2) and not (col = 'xyz' and col2 = 'abc')

This is because in RDBMS, in my case I need to have all the data in one query, so if I can just have a WHERE clause that takes into account that the other columns match my expected values and exclude the ones with errors, it would be an easy thing to work with on a higher level.

This might make more sense to you:

How can I see my network traffic?

I have a virtual server with Debian 6.0 and Apache.
I'd like to check and understand what are my incoming and outgoing traffic, but nothing shows up on top. I also use the Webmin interface to setup users, so there is no need for loggin, I just run it without asking for credentials. 
And for outgoing (I assume my server is used as a proxy, the problem is with incoming traffic) all that says is

"GET / HTTP/1.1" 301 188
  "-" "Mozilla/5.0
  (X11; U; Linux
  i586; en-GB; rv:1.9.0.1
  3100NBR) Gecko/20091103
  (1.0.0.1; X)Ubuntu/10.04"

... I have Apache running and open, as far as I can tell.

A:

You could use iptables to redirect all outbound traffic to another machine and capture the traffic there. 
iptables --table nat --append POSTROUTING --out-interface eth0 -j MASQUERADE

For incoming see

1. Field of the Disclosure
Embodiments disclosed herein relate generally to methods and apparatus for performing separation of particles in a fluid stream. More specifically, embodiments disclosed herein relate to an electrophoretic separation unit in a fluid stream.
2. Background
In many applications, it is desirable to detect and/or quantify trace elements in fluids. However, such elements may be present as an extremely small percentage of the total bulk volume of the fluid, making it difficult to detect and/or quantify trace elements with conventional chemical methods. For example, it is relatively difficult to obtain a quantitative measurement of trace elements in body fluids, such as blood, when the trace elements are present in only parts per million to parts per billion of body fluid and not at all of a control standard (e.g., water). In addition, many trace elements are naturally occurring but are commercially available as isotope-enriched or enriched preparations.
In order to solve the aforementioned problems, certain methods have been developed for concentrating trace elements in fluids. One such method is capillary electrophoresis (CE), which provides both a separation and preconcentration step.
In capillary electrophoresis, the fluid sample is injected into a capillary tube and the fluid is separated based on the electrical properties of the sample. The separated components can then be detected electrochemically or can be passed into a subsequent detector, for example, optical (e.g., laser, fluorescence, absorption), which enables quantitative detection of a specific element from the separated components.
Another separation technique involves high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), which offers numerous advantages including increased separation efficiency, improved separation resolution, automation, good solute compatibility and a rapid increase in sample throughput. The use of capillaries in HPLC has resulted in devices known as capillary chromatography. These systems consist of a capillary column packed with a stationary phase, either solid or liquid, into which a sample containing target components is introduced via a fluid stream or via sample introduction ports in the wall surface of the capillary tube, and the movement of the fluid itself is driven by a pump that forces a sample into the column and permits the solutes to selectively move along the column based on partition coefficients of the solutes with the stationary phase of the column and the solvent used.

The new Calibrachoa plant originated from a cross-pollination made by the Inventor in July, 2013 in Rheinberg, Germany of a proprietary selection of Calibrachoa sp. identified as code number A1401111204, not patented, as the female, or seed, parent with a proprietary selection of Calibrachoa sp. identified as code number F-15-00, not patented, as the male, or pollen, parent. New method for the detection of free haemoglobin in blood: application to the detection of hypovolaemic shock.
A new spectrophotometric method has been developed for the determination of free haemoglobin in red cells. The method is based on the reaction of haemoglobin with o-phenanthroline in acidic medium to form a copper-haematin complex which has characteristic absorption spectra. In the blood samples from patients with septic shock and haemorrhagic shock, this assay can detect 2 parts per million (ppm) of free haemoglobin. The method may also be useful for the detection of other anaemic states.

[Epidemiological study of urolithiasis in a pediatric population in the province of Reggio Calabria].
To date, there are few epidemiological studies of pediatric urolithiasis. For a better understanding of the determinants and effects of such a disease, and to improve the care for patients, the aim of the current study was to assess epidemiological aspects of pediatric urolithiasis in the province of Calabria. All the children that had been hospitalized in the province of Reggio Calabria in January 1999 and underwent the complete diagnostic work up for idiopathic or renal stone disease, for a period of 6 months, were included in the study. The cases of idiopathic renal stone disease were analyzed according to age, sex, seasonality of the illness, type of stone, location, presence of a metabolic disease, other pathology and previous treatment. For calculi, according to site and type, the following variables were considered: size, presence of a growth mechanism and presence of infection. Moreover, urinary parameters and serum metabolic profile were assessed. Among the 3,532 cases of idiopathic renal stone disease, 57% were female. Children under 3 years of age accounted for 26.6% of the whole group. A peak incidence of stone disease was seen from 8 to 14 years of age (34.3%). About half of the cases were diagnosed in the winter months. About two third of the lesions were found in the proximal ureter and in the distal thirds of the renal collecting system. Renal stones were found in 80.7% of the cases. The most frequent calculus type was calcium phosphate accounting for 57.5% of all the cases. Of these patients, 14.9% had a metabolic disease, 4.6% had a congenital metabolic disease, and another 11.2% had been previously surgically treated for a renal stone of the same type. Finally, urinary metabolic parameters, as well as serum calcium and phosphate were significantly correlated with stone presence. We conclude that pediatric urolithiasis is more frequent in young girls and children under 3 years. Also, the disease often occurs in non-spring months and affects both the proximal and the distal segments of the ureter. Calcium phosphate is the most common calculi found in the pediatric population. A significant proportion of patients have at least one metabolic renal stone. This invention is particularly suited for a diagnostic assay in a small instrument in which a test substrate and measuring instrument are in intimate contact in a portable testing device. The invention has applications as a point-of-care (POC) diagnostic, a laboratory test and/or an in vitro diagnostics test. The invention can be configured as a whole-blood test, a whole-serum, or a serum.
The invention is designed for a diagnostic analytical assay in a small handheld analysis device that combines test and measurement operations on the same substrate. An analyte is sensed or detected in the substrate by an electrically-conductive solid state test element, preferably a thin-film test element, and the sensor output signal is sensed by a sensing electrode to detect the presence, quantity, or concentration of the analyte.
The invention is based on biosensors that incorporate the use of electrical contacts for sensing analyte concentration. Devices have been disclosed in which two or more conductive elements are configured to measure the difference in electrochemical potential between two, adjacent layers of contact that are used to establish electrically closed electrical circuits. An example of such a device is disclosed in U.S. Pat. No. 3,532,461 (Yurkievych, 1970). The Yurkievych device is a metal/polymer-modified electrode having an insulator surrounding the metal layer and located between the metal layer and the polymer-modified surface. A second insulator layer, in contact with the metal layer, is located inside and outside the insulator to form the closed circuit. The Yurkievych electrode is designed to establish electrochemical potential difference between the metal/polymer and the metal/second metal layer. Electrochemical potentials do not vary monotonically with the concentration of an electroactive species in solution. U.S. Pat. No. 5,091,352 (Kamper et al., 1992) discloses an electrochemical cell, wherein three contact metal layers sandwich a dielectric layer, such that the metal layers together form a closed electric circuit. CoffeeScript get string value from property of object

I would like to get the value of an object's properties but without the use of brackets []. It doesn't seem right so I can't seem to get it to work how I would like.
So here is a sample object:
{id: 123, text: 'this is a test'}

I would love to get the following:
1237: this is a test

Is there a simple method or do I need to create an internal function to get this done?
Also, is this an efficient method or should I use some external library for my string manipulation?
Appreciate the help!
UPDATE:
After some more testing of the object I get the following:
{id: 123, text: 'this is a test'}
=> Object {id: 123, text: 'this is a test'}

Here the variable:
var jsonData

jsonData is defined like this:
var jsonData = {"id": 123, "text": "this is a test"}

Now this is a simplified way to get the json, but should give some insight...
The output I am trying to see is:
{id: 123, text: 'this is a test'}
=> Object {id: 123, text: 'this is a test'}

A:

You can use for in loop
for (key in object) {
    console.log(key + ":" + object[key])
    //Or the value using brackets:
    console.log(key + ":" + object[key])
}
// 1237: this is a test

All treated patients (n = 50) with documented CRSwNP (Schiller criteria) received at least 6 months of oral corticosteroid (OCS) treatment, and were followed up 12 months after the baseline evaluation (Visit 01). The primary aim was to assess the efficacy of this treatment by evaluating the results by the following variables: symptom score, endoscopical grading scale (EGS), Lund-Mackay (LM) score (LMS), nasal polyp index (NPI) and Lund-Kennedy (LK) surgery rate score. The secondary aim was to identify possible predictors to assess nonresponder patients for an alternative medical treatment. Aerophoria (album)

Aerophoria is the debut studio album by Swedish pop punk band New Found Glory. Released in January 2005 on Fueled by Ramen, the recording features two songs that would appear on the band's first album, which was nearly four years later, in September 2009.

In addition to the singles "Jaded" and "Tear Me Down" from the album, "Satellite" was also released as a single in 2003 prior to this album, and re-recorded from those demo versions.

It is one of the few records to not feature a guitar solo (unless the guitar is the bass in the song "Dance Until You're Ready" or part of the piano intro to "Goodbye"). Chris Carroll plays the drums in the recording while Eric Gusek plays the guitar.

As stated on the band's MySpace, this album also marks the first release that the band had as a five-piece.

The album was certified Gold in Sweden, and has sold over 7,000 copies to date.

Track listing
All songs written by New Found Glory, except where noted.

Jordan Pundik – lead vocals
Steve Klein – guitar
Kenny Vasoli – bass guitar
Chad Gilbert – drums

Mixed by John Armstrong at The Hideout
Mastered by Andrew Schubert

Q:

Is there an upper bound for how large numbers can be in an ECDSA signature?

It's my understanding that elliptical curves can be used for digital signatures (when $n$ is greater than 487, that is) - but is there an upper-bound on the size of the number that can be used? 
I'm looking for an explanation of how $n$ is chosen to represent the number to be signed. 

A:

The largest $n$ size that has practical security seems to be somewhere around $2^{100}$, and the general approach for choosing the size is to have the curve be a proper subgroup of a degree $2^{2k} - 1$ subfield.
I think there's at least one paper with some interesting links that talks about all this http://www.cacr.math.uwaterloo.ca/math/journals/t/tcs/volume1/tcs-v1-3.pdf

The present invention relates to an electric contact structure that can be used in electric circuits or parts of electric circuits in an automobile battery assembly.
FIG. 7 shows a conventional electric contact made of sintered material; a sintered lead or lead alloy which has a porosity of 40% to 50% and at least one of a copper and a copper alloy of low specific resistance. The electric contact is formed by means of welding, riveting and so on. Each piece of the electric contact is put into a metal mold, and the metal mold is heated at a temperature as high as 260.degree. C. so that solder is flowed between the electric contacts and between the electric contacts and a conductor. After welding, the electric contacts thus-sintered, and the conductor are subjected to soldering.
This sintering takes a long time and consumes a long time in manufacturing the electric contact.
To reduce the manufacture time and space, the inventor has invented the electric contact structure (disclosed in Japanese Patent Laid-open No. 60-96640) in which the electric contacts are each fixed in a groove made in a bottom of a metal mold in such a manner that the electric contact is formed from the bottom surface of the metal mold by machining the bottom surface. These electric contacts are arranged in a line. Then, solder is flowed between the electric contacts thus-arranged in the bottom of the metal mold. Thus, a required number of pieces of electric contacts are put into the metal mold in a single operation, and then, the metal mold is heated, so that the electric contacts are sintered.
If the electric contacts are sintered in the metal mold in this manner, however, the electric contacts are not securely fixed to the metal mold, and the electric contacts move relative to each other. Accordingly, it is difficult to flow solder between the electric contacts properly.

[Molecular biological research on DNA repair genes of tumor cell lines with microphthalmia-linked hereditary retinal degeneration].
To explore the mechanism of microphthalmia-linked hereditary retinal degeneration (MLHRD) and to develop molecular biological research techniques of MLHRD gene. Three cell lines M2D1, a retina-specific cell line and two lines L7B and M19D from MLHRD patients were investigated by PCR-SSCP, denaturing high performance liquid chromatography (DHPLC) and sequencing. SSCP analysis of MLRDB1 gene from M2D1 cell line showed the presence of 6 different band pattern and one new pattern in M2D1 cells. No mutation was found in exons 8 and 13-17 of MLRDB1 gene, but a 648 bp band was found in the same band in exon 12 in M2D1 cells. No abnormal band pattern, but one novel band in exon 2 was observed in DHPLC result of MLRDG from M19D cells. Sequencing analysis showed that homozygous mutations of MLRDB1 gene were carried in M19D cell. The mutations of MLRDB1 gene were confirmed in L7B cell and other three cell lines by PCR-SSCP and sequencing. Mutations and/or polymorphisms were not found in other exons of MLRDB1, MLRDB2 and MLRDB3. These results suggest the mutations of MLRDB1, MLRDB2 and MLRDB3 in M2D1, M19D and L7B cell lines may not contribute to the clinical manifestation of MLHRD. M2D1 cell would been useful for the DNA repair investigation in MLHRD.

A non-exposure resist pattern forming method has hitherto been known in which the light transmittance of a resist layer applied onto a substrate to be processed is measured in a non-light exposure region thereof, and development is carried out only in a non-light exposure region while the resist layer is exposed in a region other than a region in which light transmittance is low and, if exposed resist is then developed and rinsed, the film thickness of the resist pattern is controlled based on the light transmittance measured.
In such a pattern forming method, the film thickness of the developed resist pattern is sometimes not uniform in the longitudinal and transverse direction due to the effects of unevenness in development caused, for example, by temperature distribution in development or by heat accumulation in a resist layer. In case where two kinds of light sources, for example, a pulsed NdYVO.sub.4 laser and a continuous argon laser, are respectively used to form resist patterns of different thicknesses, a resist pattern of one kind of light source has different film thickness in the longitudinal and transverse direction if each film thickness cannot be controlled precisely with individual lasers or, by means of a single laser, if individual pulses cannot be used. Where the resist pattern is formed with pulsed NdYVO.sub.4 laser beams to increase productivity in production of semiconductor devices, therefore, the resist film thickness in longitudinal and transverse direction can be controlled by adjusting the number of pulses of the laser beams per unit of length in the longitudinal direction. In case where a single laser source for continuously providing laser beams is used, no control mechanism is required in forming a resist pattern of a desired length.

Predicting long-term prognosis of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage in Japan: A report of the Japanese Aneurysm Subarachnoid Hemorrhage Predictor (JASH) study.
Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (aSAH) contributes to high morbidity and mortality worldwide despite improvements in medical and surgical treatment. We performed a retrospective multicenter Japanese study to assess whether the initial status and medical treatment can sufficiently predict the prognosis after aSAH. Patients newly diagnosed with aSAH from seven institutions in Japan were enrolled. We investigated the prognosis and initial conditions to evaluate the predictability of outcome. Patients were divided into four groups according to Hunt and Hess grade, Fisher scale score, World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies grade, and the presence of blood pressure problems: (1) good-grade patients with no blood pressure problems; (2) poor-grade patients with no blood pressure problems; (3) good-grade patients with blood pressure problems; and (4) poor-grade patients with blood pressure problems. Sixty-two of 108 patients had poor-prognosis (56.5%). The initial conditions were good for 54.9% patients; poor for 37.5% patients; good-grade patients for 13.3% patients; and poor-grade patients for 5.6% patients. Patients having a good grade with no blood pressure problems had a favorable prognosis after aSAH. Patients having a poor grade with or without blood pressure problems had a poor prognosis. Initial conditions are better to predict prognosis, and medical treatment is insufficient to predict the patient's outcome.

The impact of socioeconomic conditions and family support on maternal smoking during pregnancy: evidence from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth.
The authors describe socioeconomic disparities in maternal smoking during pregnancy and the impact of family support on this relationship. A sample of 23,874 maternal smoking histories obtained from the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth during 1985 through 1995 were fit to a logistic model of the relationship between maternal socioeconomic status (education and race) and maternal smoking during pregnancy. The authors also conducted a survey of 500 pregnant women participating in the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth to assess the impact of family support on the smoking behavior of pregnant women. The relationship between maternal education and the odds of smoking during pregnancy was significantly stronger among Hispanics, blacks, and women in the lower classes relative to whites. However, there was no clear association between race and smoking during pregnancy. The odds of maternal smoking during pregnancy were higher among unmarried, younger women and women in poverty. Lower family support was associated with maternal smoking during pregnancy. The authors discuss the importance of health policy to address the problem of maternal smoking during pregnancy.

The role of endogenous and exogenous nitric oxide in vasoconstriction in the human digital vein.
Experiments were designed to determine the direct roles of endogenous and exogenous nitric oxide (NO) on responses in the microcirculation of human digital veins. The local forearm vasoconstrictor response to isometric exercise was used to test responses of the digital vascular bed under both normal and NO synthase (NOS) inhibition conditions. Human participants performed forearm isometric handgrip exercise at 30% or 60% of their maximum voluntary contraction for periods of 2, 4, and 6 minutes. Responses were measured by venous occlusion plethysmography, blood flow measured by venous Doppler ultrasound, and blood flow distribution measured by venous strain-gauge plethysmography. Compared with control conditions (n=10, 8 men, 2 women), responses following administration of the NOS inhibitor N(G)-monomethyl-L-arginine (L-NMMA) (n=7, 5 men, 2 women) were not significantly different. The response to isometric handgrip exercise was significantly reduced in the presence of the NOS inhibitor nitro-L-arginine. The percentage decreases in blood flow distribution during exercise were 11% (P=0.016), 17% (P=0.003), and 16% (P=0.01) using the L-NMMA and nitro-L-arginine. However, the reduction in blood flow distribution was not proportional to the decrease in percent blood flow. These data imply that although the response to isometric handgrip exercise in the vascular bed of the hand is dependent on nitric oxide activity, changes in the distribution of blood flow within the digital vasculature during isometric contraction is not directly mediated by nitric oxide.

[Epidemiology of cancer of the breast at the Gede Linn Cancer Institute, a retrospective study on 728 patients].
The epidemiological profile of cancer of the breast is characterized by a female prevalence, a high incidence in young women and a low mortality. The objective of the present study was to review the medical records of 728 patients in order to obtain epidemiological information on the population studied and to evaluate the epidemiological and pathological factors correlated with the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. Data collected included age at the time of the first examination, clinical and pathological data, the presence of the hormone receptors (ER, PR), Her-2 oncogene and proliferative capacity. The patients were classified into 10 age groups: 20-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59, 60-69, 70-79, 80-89 years. These groups were statistically compared with each other and compared with other published data. Histological type, grade of differentiation, lymph node involvement, and the presence of cancer were studied in comparison to other published data. Age, clinical presentation (local or metastatic), location, type of treatment and the presence of positive hormone receptors were found to be statistically correlated with the diagnosis. Histological type, grade of differentiation, lymph node involvement and Her-2 oncogene were not statistically correlated with the diagnosis.

Mortality in patients treated for HIV-1 and tuberculosis in Italy.
To describe trends in age- and sex-specific annual mortality rates during the first 15 years of the AIDS epidemic in a cohort of HIV-1-infected subjects infected with HIV-1 with or without active tuberculosis (TB), who were being treated in 12 infectious disease centers in Italy. The study population consisted of 524 subjects: 278 females and 246 males with a median age of 34.2 years (interquartile range 27.8-44.2) at diagnosis. The standardized annual mortality rate was calculated by dividing the number of deaths in a single year by the person-years observed. Standardized mortality rate estimates were stratified for sex, risk group, year of diagnosis, clinical status at study entry of HIV and TB, and site of care. Patients were classified at study entry as immunologic failures (IF) or with an AIDS defining disorder (AD). The observed mortality rate was 12.3 deaths per 100 person-years. The most frequent baseline causes of death were AIDS (74%), other infectious diseases (8.8%), cancers (6.2%) and cardiovascular diseases (3.9%). Mortality rates increased steadily from the first to the second year after HIV diagnosis from 3.0 to 5.7 deaths per 100 person-years for the cohort considered. Mortality increased with the number of active opportunistic infections, even after adjustment for the degree of immunosuppression. Mortality remained high throughout the epidemic, and even increased slightly in the late years. Mortality in HIV-infected patients with active TB has decreased with the improvement of anti-TB therapy and the introduction of antiretroviral drugs over the past decade; however, it remains significantly higher than in similar cohorts of non-AIDS-related HIV-positive patients who have not been actively treated with anti-TB drugs.

In certain applications, a fluid storage tank is placed in a horizontal position, and when filled with fluid, the tank bottom is located on the ground, so that a fluid transfer function can be effected by tilting the tank, for example to pour the fluid from an outlet at bottom level of the tank, onto the ground or into such a container as a container on a conveyor. However, for reasons of safety and convenience, the tank should be placed in a vertical position, and it can be filled, for example, by being placed on a support or conveyor. In this connection, the support or conveyor is positioned on a base which is fixed in place and is not itself movable, to permit the fluid transfer operation to proceed. Such a fixed base is known for use in connection with other fluid transfer operations.
In another application, fluid storage tanks or other storage tanks or enclosures are provided with a base, and the upper portion thereof includes a fluid outlet, for example the tank bottom. In this connection, it has been recognized that, with certain fluids such as a combustible and/or flammable fluid, for example propane, it is undesirable to permit an open flame or spark to be produced in close proximity to the storage tank in order to pour such fluids and thereby prevent the combustion of the fluid in the storage tank. This is because the spark or flame may ignite the fluid in the storage tank.
With regard to certain vehicles, such as fire trucks, it is desirable to be able to quickly and efficiently place the storage tank on a base. This is particularly important in order to prevent the storage tank from tipping over and spilling such fluids as may be contained or held within the tank. In this connection, if the fuel-containing tank is placed on a tilted base, the tank can tip over, and, depending in part, on the design of the base, spill the fuel.
It is therefore desirable to provide a container for storing a fluid, the container including a base and an enclosed compartment formed integrally in the base for holding the fluid. The container is arranged to be placed in a vertical position for filling, and thereby store, the fluid, and thereafter placed in a horizontal position while the fluid is poured and transferred from the container. How to get only the most recent values in sql server

I have a table:
ID    Timestamp    Value1     Value2
1     2012-10-01   0.4        1.4
2     2013-01-01   1.5        0.7
3     2012-10-01   1.1        0.2

I want only the newest value for each ID, so I would like to receive this out:
ID    Timestamp    Value1     Value2
2     2013-01-01   1.5        0.7
3     2012-10-01   1.1        0.2

I was thinking of doing an inner query with a where clause, can anyone help?

A:

if you just need single record per ID without group, no need to inner query.
; with topdown as
(
select T.*,
    datediff(day, top1.tid, T.tid) as top1_tid
        from mytable as T
        where top1_tid =T.tid
    order by top1_tid desc
)
select * from topdown where top1_tid <= @MyID

if you want group, you can use top 1 with group by 
with topdown as
(
select T.*,
,count(*) as cnt
from mytable as T with (nolock)
where top1_tid =T.tid
group by T.tid
)
select * from topdown where top1_tid <= @MyID
or select top1.* from topdown where top1_tid <= @MyID

Forked/Cloned repository gives different content

I've forked a repository on git, and changed its name. Then, i've opened new Terminal, and cloned the new repo using 
clone URL

After trying to pull from the repo. I get different files. Please help.

A:

This is because you cloned a fork of the same repository, and so your repository has the exact same history as the repository you cloned. You can find the parent repository at the URL of the repository you cloned from.
In addition to that, you cloned a repository with a different name, and thus it won't be able to find the same refs from the parent repository.

An evaluation of the use of an artificial disc on an intact lumbar spine model.
One of the many ways to relieve low back pain after spine surgery is through the use of nucleus replacements but they have been shown to have some limitations such as extrusion, subsidence, or migration that could cause implant loosening, or even dislocation in the case of intervertebral cages. One other way of providing interbody fusion is through the use of an allograft implant. Recently, many artificial discs are under development that are the exact size of the autograft. This is the first study that seeks to evaluate the behavior of an artificial disc under normal physiologic load conditions with varying degrees of stability. This study includes an all-femoral bone-on-bone lumbar spine model designed specifically to represent a lumbar segment with an allograft implanted. Eight fresh-frozen human cadaveric lumbar spine models were used in this study. All models were randomly divided into 2 groups, a dynamic motion group that was loaded live in a spine tester and an unloaded static group. In each group, a total of 4 models were tested with the L4-L5 segment intact, and 4 were tested with a L4-L5 posterior hemisectomy. The dynamic group was tested in static position and cycled between static loads and ranges of motion (ROMs). The allograft was placed in the L4-L5 intervertebral space of the tested segment. The static group was loaded in the same tester with the identical ROMs tested in the dynamic group. Results suggest that an artificial disc increases motion segment stiffness under physiologic loading in intact lumbar spine models that are tested in the dynamic position. The results with the allograft disc in intact lumbar spine segments suggest that the allograft disc has an effect on spine stiffness that is equal to or better than the intact segment with no allograft. This would imply that the allograft disc can be a good alternative to the autograft disc because it allows the ROM to be increased, is resistant to fatigue, and has no subsidence or migration characteristics. The allograft disc could eventually replace the autograft disc for spine stabilization in the near future.

The association between early menarche and type 2 diabetes mellitus, metabolic syndrome, and obesity in the young.
Early menarche is an important risk factor for diabetes mellitus (DM) and metabolic syndrome (MS), among other illnesses. Some studies report a relationship with obesity as well. In this study we examined the relationship among early menarche, DM, MS, and obesity. In a cross-sectional study we enrolled 16-year-old girls (mean age 15.3 ± 0.3years; N = 1174) and measured anthropometric and body composition parameters according to standardized guidelines. Early menarche, body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference (WC) were not significantly different between obese (BMI ≥ 95th% centile, n = 70 (4.9% of analyzed group)) and non-obese (n = 1164) girls, however they were significantly higher in the total group than among boys of the same age. In the multivariate logistic regression model, menarche at any age, compared to menarche after 3years was associated with an increased risk of overweight/obesity. Odds ratio (OR) = 1.7 (95%CI: 1.2, 2.2); P < 0.001), and obesity (OR = 1.7; 95%CI: 1.1, 2.6), and for central obesity with OR = 2.0 (95%CI: 1.1, 3.2), P < 0.001). Early menarche was not directly associated with DM, MS, dyslipidemias, insulin resistance and homeostasis model assessment (HOMA) score. In conclusion, even though the OR for obesity was high among the girls, this association should not be considered conclusive. Early menarche seems to influence girls' lean body mass, but not their fat mass.

The present invention relates to an apparatus for measuring the pressure of an exhaust gas and measuring the total heat produced by the gas.
FIG. 1 shows a schematic of a conventional method for detecting a pressure of an exhaust gas from an engine. As shown in FIG. 1, the total pressure 1 of exhaust gas is the sum of the static pressure 2 of an air intake tube, the differential pressure 3 between the exhaust gas pressure 1 inside the exhaust gas passage and the atmospheric pressure 4 outside the exhaust gas passage, and the pressure due to the effect of centrifugal force 5 which acts on the exhaust gas.
It will be noted that the differential pressure 3 and centrifugal force 5 act in the upstream direction of the exhaust gas because the exhaust gas in the exhaust gas passage is compressed in the upstream direction by the action of centrifugal force and then is expanded. More specifically, the exhaust gas is compressed by the centrifugal force and then is blown back through a venturi toward the atmosphere to be expanded in the atmosphere.
These differential pressure 3 and centrifugal force 5 increase due to the increased temperature of the exhaust gas, for example, at about 300.degree. C. Therefore, a greater change in the differential pressure 3 is produced than in the static pressure 2, for example, by about 30% at the above-mentioned temperature and the total pressure 1 can be detected as the sum of the static pressure 2 and the differential pressure 3.

A prospective study comparing laparoscopic and open appendectomy in children in a developing country.
Appendiceal pathology in children is common. However, the optimal management for acute appendicitis in children is still under debate. This prospective study was conducted to assess the perioperative outcome between laparoscopic and open appendectomy for acute appendicitis in children in a developing country. Two hundred children aged from 5 to 14 undergoing laparoscopic appendectomy for acute appendicitis were compared with 200 cases treated with open appendectomy. The 2 groups were compared regarding demographic profile, perioperative outcomes, and cost of care. Both groups were comparable in terms of mean age and sex. Mean operation time was shorter in the open appendectomy group (50.5 and 36.3 minutes respectively). Wound infection rates were found to be higher (8.00%) in the laparoscopic appendectomy group. Mean hospital stay was higher in the laparoscopic appendectomy group (3.22 days), but the difference was found to be statistically insignificant. The mean expense of treatment was found to be higher in the open appendectomy group (3066/- and 2422/- per operation respectively). While, the median cost of laparoscopic surgery was higher than open appendectomy (2090/- and 1350/- per operation respectively). Laparoscopic appendectomy for acute appendicitis in children carries a significant morbidity, especially wound infections. The median cost of laparoscopic appendectomy was found to be more than open approach. Further studies are required to assess the relative efficacy of laparoscopic and open appendectomy in children.

Evaluation of the effect of amlodipine on cardiovascular safety in clinical trials: results from recent meta-analyses.
Recent data indicate that amlodipine is as effective as other drugs in reducing major cardiovascular events, but it is still uncertain whether the risk of serious side effects is lower with amlodipine than with placebo or other anti-hypertensive agents. Since these drug safety issues have not been adequately evaluated in randomized controlled clinical trials, meta-analyses of data from clinical trials and randomized phase 2 studies were carried out. Several sources were searched to identify additional trials comparing amlodipine to other anti-hypertensive agents. The relative risk of myocardial infarction was analyzed in 10 trials; the relative risk of stroke in 4 trials; the relative risk of non-fatal stroke in 14 trials; and the relative risk of atrial fibrillation in 11 trials. The relative odds of myocardial infarction with amlodipine versus placebo (-0.06, 95% confidence interval -0.22 to 0.09) and versus other anti-hypertensives (+0.28, 0.16 to 0.40) were not significantly different. The odds ratios of atrial fibrillation with amlodipine versus placebo (1.03) and versus other anti-hypertensives (0.84) were not different after accounting for possible publication bias. Amlodipine does not increase the odds of myocardial infarction or atrial fibrillation when compared with other anti-hypertensive agents. These findings confirm the safety profile of amlodipine previously established in controlled clinical trials.

Pseudomonas putida-induced formation of bio-oil from sewage sludge at mild temperatures.
In this study, the effects of using Pseudomonas putida (PTCC 1731) and anaerobic digestion on sewage sludge hydrolysis and bio-oil formation were examined. Anaerobically digested sewage sludge, containing no inoculant, was hydrolyzed at 60 degrees C under mild conditions with or without inoculant (P. putida). The effects of heating period of 24, 48 and 72 h on the hydrolysis and subsequent bioethanol and biomass production were investigated. Inoculating sewage sludge with a P. putida culture resulted in better hydrolysis (60.5% of total solids) yield and ethanol productivity compared to untreated sewage sludge (49.0% of total solids and 0.34 g ethanol/L) after 72 h of heating. The highest hydrolysis and bioethanol productions occurred after 72 h of incubation. When the heating time was shortened to 48 h, ethanol in the hydrolyzed solution reached only 23.2% of the ethanol yield derived from the initial dry solid material. In this hydrolysis process, the amount of total solids, total saccharification and solid residue was increased by the inoculation with P. putida, whereas the bio-oil percentage was reduced from 33.8% (untreated sewage sludge) to 22.2% after 72 h of incubation. The data presented in this study indicate that the combined use of anaerobic digestion and P. putida induced hydrolysis is a better process to provide a new bioethanol and bio-oil-based renewable energy.

Dietary supplementation of the fatty alcohol, 12-hydroxydodecanoic acid, ameliorates metabolic syndrome in insulin-resistant obese C57BL/6J mice.
The long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid, docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), is the major polyunsaturate of the brain, and has been implicated in the prevention of Alzheimer's disease and obesity. However, the fatty alcohol 12-hydroxydodecanoic acid (12-HDA) is also a component of the human brain, and is formed by the sequential actions of fatty alcohol dehydrogenase from decanoic acid and lauric acid or omega-3 fatty acid desaturases from DHA. We aimed to determine whether 12-HDA supplementation could be effective for the treatment of metabolic syndrome using an insulin-resistant obese mouse model. Twelve-week-old C57BL/6J mice received 12-HDA (30mg/kg diet) or olive oil (as a control) for 11 days. Body weight, body fat percentage, serum triglyceride, serum glucose, insulin secretion and hepatic glycogen content were higher in 12-HDA-treated obese mice than in the control mice, with decreased triglyceride/HDL-cholesterol ratio (P<0.05). Insulin homeostasis test revealed that the intra-peritoneal glucose tolerance test (IpGTT) and oral (1 g/kg) glucose tolerance test (IoGTT) were improved in 12-HDA-treated obese mice compared with the control mice (P<0.05). This resulted from elevated insulin sensitivity as measured by the IpGTT (P<0.05) and insulin sensitivity index (P<0.05) calculated from IpGTT and IoGTT. Furthermore, 12-HDA treatment reduced inflammation (P<0.05) and ameliorated hepatosteatosis (P<0.05). Importantly, 12-HDA treatment had more favorable impact on metabolic syndrome than fish oil treatment. 12-HDA supplementation ameliorated metabolic syndrome in insulin-resistant obese mice. Our observations suggest that 12-HDA supplementation may be effective for the prevention and treatment of metabolic syndrome.

Q:

Prove that $\text{div}(\text{grad}(\phi))= \nabla(\text{div} \phi)$ for $\phi$ is harmonic

Let $\phi$ be a harmonic function with harmonic gradient $\nabla(\phi)$. Can anyone tell me how to prove that $\text{div}(\text{grad}(\phi))= \nabla(\text{div} \phi)$?

A:

Harmonic implies $\nabla \cdot \nabla\phi = 0$. Then applying the divergence operator on both sides gives the result. Note that $\nabla \times \nabla\phi = 0$ is not sufficient, but the divergence of the curl gives the gradient of the divergence.

answer: Loss of a key gene required for the survival of normal tissue in the Drosophila imaginal tissues leads to tissue overgrowth and lethality. The gene, lethal giant larvae, encodes a protein with homologues in Drosophila and mammals. The major goal of this proposal is to characterize the role this gene plays in normal tissue in the Drosophila imagina. The specific aims of the proposed work are: 1. To determine the relationship between lethal giant larvae expression and normal development in the eye in the third instar. These experiments will involve analysis of lethal mutants, as well as chimeras with tissue specific lethal genes. 2. To study the role lethal giant larvae plays in embryonic development in terms of its ability to rescue embryonic lethal mutations. 3. To determine if lethal giant larvae has function in the normal development of ovaries by analysis of mutant ovaries. [MI]

A new generation of powerful cameras that can capture up to 30 frames per second in four-dimensional time--as well as other kinds of motion--has moved a little closer to reality.

Engineers at MIT and at the University of Stuttgart, Germany, have invented a prototype camera that can do both kinds of video capture using one sensor with 16 layers on it--a type of 3D video that combines multiple slices in a single frame. The layers are all recorded so that they can be overlapped to generate the 4D video. And the camera's four different parts, each designed for one of the video modes, are manufactured by an all-inkjet fabrication process that requires only one simple, low-cost step.

There's also a new type of lighting system developed by the group's professor of electrical engineering, Kostas Kalliakos, with a set of new, nonstandard lenses that produce the right amount of light for every one of the 16 layers on the camera's sensor.

When the whole system is hooked up to a micro controller, it can record images with up to 16 layers in a single frame--enough to produce 4D video.

The researchers describe all of this in a paper they published July 17 in the journal Nature.

The next step, they say, is to test it in real world settings, including a concert hall, a conference center, and other places where fast-moving events in multiple dimensions are common. They want to see how well the 4D video captures all the data from these events, and also how well the lighting system performs.

Previous work on capturing both kinds of motion data has used separate cameras, one for capturing images, another for capturing a time sequence. The MIT and Stuttgart groups' single camera system can capture both kinds of data in a single frame.

Morphological changes during cell cycle of human leukemic monocytic (U937) cells.
The morphology of several phases of the cell cycle of human leukemic monocytic (U937) cells was examined and compared with normal monocytes. Asynchronously growing leukemic U937 cells showed a similar morphology in all phases as the G0 population, consisting of one to four nuclei, nucleoli and cytoplasm. The cell volume (V) was on average 20.1 fl, as compared to 12.1 fl for normal monocytes. After 24 hrs of cultivation in serum-free (hormonally inactive) medium (SFM), U937 cells started to proliferate but had little proliferative ability since the amount of S cell fraction was on average 15% of G0 fraction after 72 hrs in SFM. When these monocytes were stimulated with phorbol 12-myristate 12-acetate, the proportion of S + G2 + M cell fraction increased dramatically with a concominant reduction of G0 fraction. U937 cells have a significantly higher proportion of S + G2 + M (60%) compared to the normal monocytes. This proportion was unchanged during 72 hrs cultivation in SFM, but a significant drop to about 42% was detected when serum was introduced to SFM cultures, indicating that a serum component stimulates the monocyte proliferation, as well as the decrease in the proportion of cells in G0 phase in serum-free medium, probably through the induction of quiescence. In addition, the percentage of G0 phase cells returned to a normal level when the cells were preincubated in serum-containing medium before introduction to SFM.

Numerous products are available for the mass sterilization of substrates, such as personal care products, diapers, medical care products, hospital supplies, and the like, where sterilization or germicidal efficacy and lack of impact on the substrate are desired. In the latter personal care products and medical care products, for example, it is often not just only sterilization or germicidal efficacy and lack of impact on the substrate desired; for such use, it usually is desired for the treatment products to be free of substances that may cause irritation, which materials have limited effectiveness for the same desired purposes in terms of, in such products, sterlization or germicidal efficacy or lack of impact on the substrates to be treated. It is particularly difficult to avoid irritating substances, because many active materials often employed for treating substrates to effect certain desired effects—e.g., as antimicrobials—also have been found to be irritating substances when employed with skin or hair; for example, alcohols, particularly the C1-C3 alcohols, such as ethanol, are effective antimicrobials for many sterilizing/germicidal compositions, but are severely irritating when applied directly to skin. Accordingly, an important aspect of the formulation of many sterilizing or germicidal compositions is the careful selection of materials which have the desired activity in the desired amount, but which, if applied directly to the person being treated, will not cause irritation.
Various germicidal agents are disclosed in the prior art, as for example in U.S. Pat. Nos. 5,543,205, 5,512,278, 5,451,356, 5,395,634, and 5,354,590, for the treatment of skin. It remains desirable to obtain the benefit of such germicidal substances, in the form of germicidal formulations containing them as active ingredients, which formulations are substantially free of irritating substances; it is particularly desirable in this regard to avoid the use of alcohols (such as alcohols having 1 to 3 carbon atoms) to the extent that it is possible to do so, and also to avoid the use of alkane sulfonates (such as sodium and potassium alkylaryl sulfonate) in such formulation, because such materials are believed to cause substantial irritation.
It is known that esters of parahydroxybenzoic acid can provide certain benefits in personal care personal care products, such as sunscreen, for skin; see for example U.S. Pat. No. 5,389

After his retirement from public service, he became the Democratic leader of the Ohio House of Representatives, and he served until his retirement at the age of 73 in 1990. My parents have always been Democrats. My mother has voted for both Democratic and Republican candidates in the past, but always votes for Democrats. She has made it a point to vote for Democratic candidates whenever they have come or will be coming to serve our county. I would hope you, as my constituents, would do much the same thing! While this is a long time coming, I have decided it is time to move toward the next step in my political career. answer: Drywall is a major construction material used to span a distance between two walls. Drywall is known to be used primarily for interior applications. Drywall is usually created by sandwiching paper between two planar sheets of fiberglass mat, called ‘kraft’ paper, with an adhesive that typically requires high humidity in order to perform adequately. When properly applied, a drywall joint holds well after extended periods of time due to the inherent stiffness and stability of the drywall. However, in spite of being a well-performing construction material, drywall joints occasionally become loose and/or water may penetrate and collect behind drywall joints. This can be a very severe problem in a typical structure in which drywall joints are located in proximity to structural shear web members such as studs that may fail in the event of a load exerted on the structure. Once such failure occurs, the structural integrity of the structural framing could potentially fail. Unfortunately, it is often difficult to predict when the structural integrity of a structure will fail and prior structural failure of drywall joints has been difficult to prevent.

Q:

Is there a way to save and restore all my apps on Android?

I have read several times that we should not backup our apps. I just wonder if there a way to save the list of all installed apps to some storage to restore when I install a new Android device where I can restore all the default apps.
There is the Android SDK Manager that allows to reinstall all the default apps and their config and data with the "Reset apps" option but is there any other app that can do that? If not, do you think it is possible without rooting the device without any extra app installed?
On the app Market, it is also possible with backups of apps where you can restore all the default apps. But there is always the option to download the apps again from the Market and install them.

A:

You can save this information to /sdcard/Android/data/com.android.providers.settings/databases/settings.db, this location doesn't require root access
I read this information from AOSP and it's confirmed on several sites (including Google Apps Dev pages)

A:

Actually it is possible to backup the list of installed apps. I read it from the source code for the apps Backup service.
To backup the list of apps just use:
adb backup -apk app.apk -shared -noapk

To restore the apps just use:
adb restore /data/data/com.android.providers.settings/databases/settings.db

Pine Street: A Day in the Life

Pine Street: A Day in the Life is an American documentary television series, which debuted August 10, 2013. Produced by American Public Television, the series profiles various American cities' local street culture.

Featured areas of the United States profiled on the show include: St Louis, New York City, Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, Seattle, Portland, San Francisco, Austin and more cities. It is produced by American Public Television, in association with KERA Productions, LLC.

The series is directed by John Caleo and produced by Steve Shaffer, who had been the director-producer on The Dust Bowl for PBS.

Synopsis
The show follows street life in cities and towns across the United States.

Episodes
Each episode on the show features a different street in a different North American city within that episode's time frame. The series includes a city guide to each segment.

Awards
2014: Chicago - Creative Child Media, Chicago Tribune's "Best Of" Award, Chicago Film & TV Awards 
2015: St. Louis, MO - Creative Child Media, St. Louis Post-Dispatch "Best of SLM" Award
2018: San Francisco, CA - Best of Fest, San Francisco International Film Festival

Use this to get file size:
<?php
    $size=filesize("file");
?>

you can use this command for local files:
<?php
    $size=filesize("~/file.txt");
?>

you can also use this for remote files:
<?php
    $size=filesize("http://example.com/file.txt");
?>

And to get size of the upload:
<?php
    $size=$_FILES["file"]["size"];
?>

The effect of a multidisciplinary cognitive-behavioural group intervention on the health and quality of life of people with mild dementia in a day care setting.
This study examined the effect of a cognitive-behavioural group intervention on the health and quality of life (QOL) of people with mild dementia who were in an in-patient day care setting in England. One hundred and sixty people with mild dementia were randomly allocated to either the experimental group (n = 79) or control group (n = 81). After 15 months, the experimental group showed significantly improved mood/anxiety and self-efficacy, QOL and cognitive function than the control group. Furthermore, this study suggested that the intervention would have additional effects on participants with additional risk factors.

The present invention is related to a method of treating the surfaces of molds used to form ceramic articles with an organopolysiloxane composition which is coated onto the surface of the mold and is cured to a highly abrasion resistant elastomerized organopolysiloxane resin after which the mold is heated to a temperature sufficient to cause the organo-polysiloxane to elastomerize. The invention is even more particularly related to the elastomerization of dimethylpolysiloxane-containing organopolysiloxane compositions which are applied to molds used to form ceramic articles.
Many materials or compounds are sensitive to the action of heat and light. Glass, porcelain enamels, epoxies, elastomers and polyesters which have good properties when applied or embedded in, or set in, a base or substrate are known to lose some or most of their properties and become brittle and inflexible when subjected to the energy associated with curing. As a result, it is difficult to manufacture a wide variety of ceramic articles from molds containing such coatings.
In the past, it has been the practice to apply to molds in ceramic articles, polysiloxanes, either alone or in the presence of other compounds, to improve the adhesion of ceramics to a metal base, which base typically comprises a ferrous based alloy when fired at the temperatures common in the use of a mold to manufacture ceramic articles. The method of applying the polysiloxane usually involves cleaning the mold surface followed by applying a quantity of the polysiloxane to the surface of the mold with a brush or by dipping the mold into a container of the material. Upon application of the polysiloxane, the mold is usually rinsed and dried by means which will not cause undesirable effects during the firing of the mold.
U.S. Pat. No. 4,066,722 discloses a polysiloxane-containing coating composition for molds which comprises a mixture of a hydroxy-terminated polydimethylsiloxane polymer, a chlorinated organosilane and a phenolic inhibitor. U.S. Pat. No. 3,993,717 describes a method for coating the inner surface of a mold to be used to form ceramic articles comprising cleaning the surfaces of the mold with an aqueous solution of a surfactant, applying to the cleaned surfaces a uniform layer of polysiloxane and drying the coated surfaces of the mold

It’s been roughly 36 hours since the New York Knicks were eliminated from the playoffs. At some point there will be an attempt at a press conference, where the players and coaches will try to make their fans forget that they ever existed. Knicks fans are all but completely blind to the team’s talent because they are stuck in a spiral of hope. In the case of head coach Jeff Hornacek, fans will soon be rooting for the former Phoenix Suns and New York Knicks head coach to help someone else get their job back.

However, Hornacek will continue to try to make his job a reality at the Knicks. At a press conference last weekend he said he was “committed” to being the head coach in New York. He’s not wrong; he’s even got a good relationship with team president Phil Jackson. Hornacek is a good fit for the Knicks because he is similar to Jackson with the way he runs his team. And this has led the most interesting part of the season to come about — fans have begun talking about Hornacek as the guy who could replace Jackson if he left as team president.

The Knicks have been linked to names like Stan Van Gundy, Rick Adelman and even Steve Kerr. While they will make a decision with Jackson in the spring, Hornacek is the one name being thrown around in potential interim replacement. There won’t be any other “interim” job available to Hornacek, so his best hope is for Jackson to leave. And at least one longtime source said he’s already resigned himself to the fact.

“He is a coach first and foremost and he will remain a coach no matter what, but if that opportunity presents itself, he would say yes,” the source said.

Now, the source added it would be a “riskier” situation than with Jackson because there’s not a history with him and team owner James Dolan, and not much “back story” to his resume.

At the end of the day the Knicks decision will be made with the goal of putting a successful team on the floor. And that’s all there really is. It doesn’t have to mean anything else. Hornacek, while a likable personality off the court, has struggled to find the success he had in Phoenix, which should tell fans all they need to know. He’s
